urn:contentItem:58T8-8CS1-JD3N-540N-00000-00SOLE SURVIVOR - This is the man who escaped an inferno that killed 19 mates2013-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 24SOLE SURVIVOR - This is the man who escaped an inferno that killed 19 mates

PRESCOTT, Arizona: Investigators from across the US have poured into an Arizona town to learn why 19 elite firefighters died in an out-of-control wildfire and whether human error played a role.

The investigation follows a memorial service at the Prescott high school football field that attracted about 3000 people, including the surviving Granite Mountain Interagency Hotshot crew member Brendan McDonough, 21.

At the end of the ceremony the organisers acknowledged Mr McDonough and the crowd gave him a standing ovation.

The investigation into the country's biggest loss of firefighters since September 11, 2001, will look at whether the crew paid attention to the forecast, created an escape route, and took other precautions developed after a similar disaster in Colorado nearly two decades ago.

The team also will look at whether the crew should have been pulled out before the fire exploded.

Within hours on Sunday, violent wind turned what was believed to be a relatively manageable, lightning-ignited forest fire into a death trap. In a desperate attempt at survival, the firefighters unfurled their foil-lined emergency shelters, but those offer only limited protection when in the direct path of a fire.

The lone survivor was serving as a lookout and relaying key information to his colleagues, officials said.

Mr McDonough notified the others that the weather was changing rapidly and that the fire had switched direction because of the wind. He told them he was leaving and to contact him on the radio if they needed anything, said Wade Ward, a Prescott Fire Department spokesman.

He said Mr McDonough ``did exactly what he was supposed to''.

Mr McDonough ``has no desire to speak to anybody at this point,'' he added.

The US Government overhauled its safety procedures following the deaths of 14 firefighters in Colorado in 1994. ``There are so many striking parallels between this tragedy and what happened on Storm King in 1994, it's almost haunting,'' said Lloyd Burton, professor of environmental law and policy at the University of Colorado.

Changes included policies under which no firefighters should be deployed unless they had a safe place to retreat. They must also be continuously informed of changing weather.

The Hotshot team entered the smoky wilderness over the weekend with backpacks, chainsaws and other heavy gear to remove brush and trees and deprive the flames of fuel. But the blaze grew from 80ha to about 800ha in hours.

More than 400 firefighters are now working on the blaze after the wildfire quadrupled from 800 hectares to more than 3200ha.

urn:contentItem:5V6X-P3V1-JD34-V1WW-00000-00Benloch fire under control2019-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisBenloch fire under controlElspeth Kernebone Chris Pedler Emma D'Agostino

CLICK HERE FOR ROLLING NEWS COVERAGE

UPDATE, Thursday 4pm:

The Country Fire Authority has reiterated advice for people near the Benloch bushfire to monitor changes to the situation overnight.

The fire is south of Kitchenhams Road and has burnt about 38 hectares. It is contained, but the CFA said there was still some fire activity within the containment lines.

"Variable wind conditions may increase this activity and smoke may be visible from nearby roads," the advice message said.

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should plan for what you will do if the situation changes."

The CFA said increased wind speed, a change in wind direction, increased smoke or poor visibility could indicate the situation was changing.

Residents of Benloch, Pastoria East, Nulla Vale, and Baynton have been urged to review their fire survival plan.

"If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes," the advice message said.

Residents have been advised there might be increased traffic and areas of raised dust.

"Drive carefully and keep the roads clear where possible," message said.

"If you need to seek emergency relief contact Macedon Ranges Shire Council on 5422 0333. They may be able to assist with basic needs including accommodation or clothing, financial aid and help with pets and livestock."

UPDATE, Wednesday 5.25pm:

The Country Fire Authority has advised people near the Benloch bushfire to monitor changes to the situation overnight.

"Increased wind speed, a change in wind direction, increased smoke or poor visibility can indicate that the situation is changing," the message for Benloch, Pastoria East, Nulla Vale and Baynton said.

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should plan for what you will do if the situation changes."

The fire, at Kitchenhams Road, has burnt about 38 hectares.

The CFA said there was still some fire activity within the containment lines, which could increase overnight with variable with conditions.

"Firefighters worked throughout Wednesday to strengthen and consolidate containment lines," the message said.

"Smoke might be visible from nearby roads."

The CFA suggested residents in the warning area charge their mobile phones in case the situation changed.

"Pack a car phone charger or spare battery...check the batteries in your radio," the message said.

"Review your fire survival plan. If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes."

Firefighters will be on scene overnight and into Thursday morning, and bulldozers and aircraft might be operating in the area.

"If you need to seek emergency relief contact Macedon Ranges Shire Council on 5422 0333. They may be able to assist with basic needs including accommodation or clothing, financial aid and help with pets and livestock," the message said.

UPDATE, 8.46pm:

The CFA has downgraded the threat to residents in areas surrounding the Benloch fire.

An advice message has been issued for Benloch, Pastoria East, Nulla Vale and Baynton.

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions," the message says.

Firefighters remain at the scene and will work throughout the night to make the fire safe.

The fire is about 25 hectares in size and has not crossed any roads.

Traffic management points at Feeneys Lane and Kitchenhams Road, Frosts Road and Burke & Wills Track, and Burke & Wills Track and Feeneys Lane have been removed.

All roads are now open.

Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.

UPDATE, 7pm:

The CFA has issued a Watch and Act message for Benloch, Pastoria East, Nulla Vale and Baynton for a bushfire at Kitchenhams Road, Benloch.

The fire is under control and has burnt about 25 hectares. It has not crossed any roads at this stage.

People who live in the warning area and are away from home are advised not to return. Those who are at home have been urged not to wait.

'Leaving now is the safest option,' the message says.

'Conditions may change and get worse very quickly.'

The CFA has advised people to monitor for signs that indicate the situation is changing, including increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility.

"If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave," the message says.

"Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.

"Emergency services might not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

Traffic management points are in place at Feeneys Lane and Kitchenhams Road; Frosts Road and Burke & Wills Track; and Burke & Wills Track and Feeneys Lane.

UPDATE, 3.50pm:

The bushfire in Kitchenhams Road Benloch has been declared under control.

READ MORE: Homes and lives were under threat as firefighters battled Benloch blaze

2.14pm: The bushfire in Kitchenhams Road, Benloch, is threatening homes and lives as it moves in a westerly direction. Vic Emergency is advising residents in the area to take shelter indoors immediately as the fire is not yet under control.

The next update is expected at 3.10pm, the current warning reads:

"You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

You should move indoors:

If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:

If you are travelling:

If you are caught in fire in your car:

Impacts in your area:

If you can smell smoke, please note:

Smoke can affect people's health.

People with pre-existing health problems, heart or lung conditions (including asthma), children, pregnant women and older people are more sensitive to the effects of breathing in smoke.

People with existing heart or lung conditions (including asthma) should follow the treatment plan advised by the doctor.

Health information:

If you need medical advice for burns or exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).

If you cannot smell smoke you are not likely to be exposed to smoke and it will therefore not affect you.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au.

VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.

VicEmergency app.

Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).

Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.

If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

UPDATE, 2.08pm: A CFA spokesman confirmed three firefighting aircraft are on route to the fire in Benloch.

Four CFA crews are currently on site and working to control the blaze which covers 300 square metres.

A further 12 CFA crews are route to the fire.

The CFA spokesman could not confirmed what started the fire.

EARLIER: An advice message has been issued for Kitchenhams Road as the Country Fire Authority fight a scrub fire that has broken out in Benloch.

The fire covers an area of 300 square metres. Fourteen appliances are attending the fire.

The CFA has advised that there is currently no threat to people in the area, but that they should stay informed and monitor conditions.

Read more: Bushfire survival kits should be ready, severe conditions declared for January 15

Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.

Crews were called to the scene just after 1pm.

CFA are working alongside police and Forest Fire Management Victoria at the scene.

People in the area should monitor changes including increased wind speed, change in wind direction and smoke or poor visibility that indicate the situation is changing.

Smoke can affect people's health, particularly those with heart or lung conditions, children, pregnant women and elderly people. People with existing medical conditions should follow the treatment plan advised by their doctor.

urn:contentItem:7XYJ-GX10-YBDY-R4JN-00000-00Fire sensors on trial2010-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Fire sensors on trialTechnology| Emily Webb

THE Shire of Yarra Ranges will be a priority area for state-of-the-art bushfire-detection sensors if a federal government trial is deemed a success.

At a community briefing in Healesville hosted by McEwen federal Liberal MP Fran Bailey last Wednesday, members of the CFA and residents of high bushfire-risk areas were told about the bushfire detection sensors being trialled in the Otways.

The sensors can tell the difference between a forest fire, dust, cloud or mist.

Mrs Bailey said she thought the Dandenong Ranges would be an ideal and high-priority location for the technology.

``It is my fervent hope that the government will fund an early technological detection system and obviously that would have to be rolled out in all of the high fire-prone risk areas,'' Mrs Bailey said.

``That will be a decision for government and it will be very interesting whether it will be the federal or state governments and whether we have a meeting of minds,'' she said.

As reported in Leader last year (August 10, 2009) the German-designed system from FireWatch Australia found support from Mrs Bailey who approached Prime Minister Kevin Rudd to authorise the trial, which began in February and will finish in May.

Mrs Bailey travelled to Europe last year to inspect the technology and state her case to the Prime Minister for the trial.

FireWatch Australia chief executive David Goodrich said the detection sensors that were founded on aerospace technology developed for the United States' National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) were not a ``total solution'' for combating bushfires but a ``fabulous tool''.

Mr Goodrich said the technology spotted its first fire on March 2 in one of the trial areas.

``The fire was 42km from the tower where the sensors were installed,'' Mr Goodrich said.

Should we trial such a fire-spotting system in the high bushfire-prone Yarra Ranges? Have your say at lilydaleleader.com.au

urn:contentItem:54X8-W3G1-JD34-V335-00000-00Firefighter gets in on the ground floor2012-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisCLASSIFIEDPg. 55Firefighter gets in on the ground floor

Ashley Miller, a firefighter who loves the Aussie outdoors, talks with Rebecca Miller

What I do: I work for the Department of Sustainability and Environment as a firefighter, preventing and responding to fires on public land. I'm learning to operate plant machinery to prevent fires spreading. I have always been part of the ground firefighter crew, training and remaining on standby to respond to fires. I work with a rake hoe crew felling dangerous trees and driving a 4WD with many litres of water, and am part of the crew on a fire tanker. I am involved with care and maintenance of recreation walking tracks, campsites and historical and environmental areas of significance.

How I got here: I studied natural resource management at TAFE. During work placement in state parks, I met forest-fire crews and decided to build a career. I began as a seasonal project firefighter then moved into managing project firefighters and fire recovery program contracts and on to what I do now.

My typical week: Each unique week involves keeping fit, forest patrols, training, maintenance of fuel breaks, roads/tracks and fire equipment. From chainsawing after a wind storm or flying in a helicopter over rugged bush terrain to work on controlling lightning strike damage, my work is very diverse. I also maintain fire pumps or climb fire towers as a fire spotter.

The good bits: I like being able to work in the great Australian outdoors. I enjoy the variety in my role as each day is different. The team I work with is great and we have a strong sense of camaraderie.

Work stress: There's plenty of paperwork, which can be painstaking and stressful to complete, but it has to be done. Obtaining all the facts and information is imperative. Generally, I tend not to let things stress me out at work.

How I relax: During the week, I enjoy going jogging after work with my dog or listening to my iPod. On weekends, I like seeing a live band with mates and unwinding with a drink.

The next step: I plan to continue operating machinery and training. I look forward to gaining more experience, mentoring crew members and managing larger-scale incidents.

urn:contentItem:5S5H-FRK1-F0J6-J02N-00000-00Deliberate smoke pollution makes a mockery of our climate alarm2018-04-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Deliberate smoke pollution makes a mockery of our climate alarmDavid.Ellery

Ah, Canberra in the autumn. There's nothing quite like it. The stinging in the eyes, the burning in the throat, the headaches and coughing. Days that would be clear and bright if the whole city wasn't suffocating under a thick layer of forest fire smoke.

Smoke so thick that the Brindabellas are obscured, and even the Telstra Tower is cloaked in haze for days on end. All the result of fires deliberately lit by the agencies that are supposed to be protecting the population, and instead ensure we are subjected to poisonous pollution for weeks on end, year after year.

What is the point of taking action to limit our carbon emissions, if our own government agencies simply dump all the carbon stored in bush vegetation back into the atmosphere every autumn?

Why do we bother phasing out wood-burning heaters, if autumn back-burning ignites 10 times the amount of wood all the wood stoves in Canberra could possibly consume? Why invest in zero-emissions cars, if the government agencies undertake maximum-emissions burns in the forests?

Why clean up a few hundred asbestos-contaminated houses if we then contaminate the air in every single house with poisonous smoke? Canberra used to pride itself on how clean our drinking water was, what does it matter if every lungful of air is thick with toxins?

Maybe these activities reduce the chance of material losses once in 50 or 100 years, but they definitely expose the entire population of the city to serious health risks - every single year.

It's incredible that the autumn burn-offs are allowed to continue.

Jon Smillie, Duffy

Ease burden on needy

The delay in passing the government's "flagship" tax package provides the opportunity to pause and reflect ("Coalition forced to pull flagship tax bill", March 28, p1).

The government can now consider lowering the tax cut to big companies and allocate the increased revenue available to areas of greater need. The boost to the economy will be much the same, as will the trickle-down effect, which is usually less than the government estimates anyway. Part of the increased revenue can be used to lessen the effects of the Welfare "Reform" Act and to increase the level of unemployment benefits.

The increase of 50¢ a week provided to single people, for example, is scandalous ("Sympathy's owing to truly poor", March 26, p39).

Herman van de Brug, Kaleen

Musts for unit dwellers

Since the ACT government is keen for many more Canberrans to make apartments their principal place of residence, it needs to act to recognise the problems that have been reported for years and restore the community's faith in its ability to manage the future development of our city ("Developer settles dispute over defects in Braddon apartment complex", canberratimes.com.au April 23).

Many wishing to downsize, for example, will be loath to make any moves until they can be assured of being able to reside in a high-quality, stress-free environment.

The ACT government could recognise growing community concern and the need for up-to-date information about building quality by:

1. giving the 2019 Canberra Citizen of the Year Award to the body corporate and residents' committee of the Lagani Apartments in Braddon for their outstanding service to the community in revealing the worrying issues and impacts concerning their decade-long battle through the courts to achieve funding for the rectification of major building deficiencies in their complex.

2. reimbursing all government rates and fees paid by owners of deficient buildings, including both houses and apartments, calculated from date of occupation to the satisfactory rectification of defects.

3. establishing a publicly accessible list of all future building developments and those that have been constructed over the past 20 years or so, containing key developer and builder details, any subsequent changes of name or liquidations of companies involved in construction, and links to the means of discovering whether action is being taken to rectify major defects.

Sue Dyer, Downer

Light rail justified ...

Max Flint (Letters, May 17) made several unfortunate claims and smears against UnionsACT and our affiliates.

Mr Flint has spent several years heading up the "Can the Tram" group.

He now goes under a new badge, but has not stopped his light-rail bashing or his union bashing.

The truth is that UnionsACT does not have a veto over ACT government contracts.

This is a fever-dream imagined by Michaelia Cash and the Canberra Liberals.

UnionsACT supports light rail because it creates secure local jobs, improves public transport services, and stimulates the local economy. However, Mr Flint insinuates that we receive a benefit ("gravy train").

He is wrong.

Mr Flint also suggests that I am lying about the results.

He is wrong. I provided the results to The Canberra Times, including the question.

The results are also on our website.

The sampling methodology is well known and performed by Reachtel, a respected polling company.

It is sad that Mr Flint still cannot accept that most Canberrans supported light rail stage one.

It is even sadder that he refuses to accept that most Canberrans support stage two.

Alex White, UnionsACT, Canberra

... but buses more so

Most respondents who supported the light rail expansion in the UnionsACT poll on light rail conducted on March 16 were undoubtedly sold a pig in a poke.

("Half of Canberrans support light rail expansion: union poll" April 9).

If, as I feel sure, the participants were not made aware that the vast majority of experts believe that a bus system is a far more cost-effective public transport investment for the entire Canberra region, and that driverless vehicle technology is predicted to deliver vastly improved public transport within a decade, then only 51.5 per cent of respondents supporting light rail is a damning result.

If Senator Seselja can bring about a federal parliamentary inquiry into the construction of light rail stage two in which these wider issues can be fully exposed, he will be doing a great service to all Canberra citizens.

John L Smith, Farrer

Is PM royal or loyal?

Reports that our PM in private debate endorsed the UK royals as permanently heading the Commonwealth need his explanation.

If true they are neither democratic nor republican.

Bryan Lobascher, Chifley

urn:contentItem:5DNS-6W01-JCM0-62PS-00000-00Scratching lyrebirds create forest firebreaks2014-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisScratching lyrebirds create forest firebreaksAnna Salleh

Australia's superb lyrebird clears litter and seedlings from the forest floor, reducing the likelihood and intensity of bushfires, new research suggests.

The birds' activity also preserves their preferred habitat of an open forest floor, says fire ecologist, Dr Steve Leonard of La Trobe University .

"They're reducing fuel by their foraging," he says. "Our hypothesis is that they are protecting their favoured habitat - not necessarily consciously, but there's a feedback going on."

Lyrebirds have powerful legs with long toes and claws that make it easy for them to rake over dead leaves and soil in the search for insects, spiders, frogs, and other small invertebrates.

"They forage like chickens," says Leonard.

By doing this, they mix litter into the soil, helping it to decompose quicker, and reducing the fuel load on the forest floor. Seedlings can also be uprooted in this process.

During research in the central highlands of Victoria following the Black Saturday fires, Leonard and colleagues noticed that areas that had been heavily worked over by lyrebirds were less likely to be burnt.

"We kept seeing the fire had stopped at the margins of gullies where there was obviously lots of lyrebird activity," he says.

"So we started wondering whether they were affecting the fire behaviour."

Open forest floor

In a study reported recently in Wildlife Research, Leonard and colleagues found that lyrebirds are more common in unburnt areas.

The study, led by Daniel Nugent, found the birds prefer an open forest floor with a layer of shrubs at two metres, says Leonard.

"It makes it easy for them to get around and forage," he says.

By contrast, the severely burnt forest areas in the study had a very thick undergrowth with thousands of eucalypt seedlings which would make it harder for the birds to forage, says Leonard.

"When you have a high intensity fire lyrebirds get killed ... and then you have this mass regeneration of vegetation," he says.

"The lyrebirds can't forage as effectively, which means you end up with more fuel so the area is more prone to burning.

"You have this feedback loop between high severity fire and low abundance of lyrebirds."

Fuel loads

Leonard and colleagues fenced off areas in the forest to exclude the lyrebirds for a period of nine months. They then measured the fuel load in these areas and compared it to the load in areas next door where lyrebirds were active.

They found the areas with lyrebirds had on average 25 per cent lower fuel loads, equating to 1.6 tonnes per hectare less fuel.

The maximum difference was 7.5 tonnes per hectares over the nine months, adds Leonard.

The researchers plugged the fuel load figures into a Forest Fire Danger Index model to predict the intensity of fire that could occur under different weather conditions.

They found that in the unfenced plots there was a significant reduction in predicted flame height.

"The lyrebirds were essentially reducing fuel loads to the extent that it was very unlikely that a fire would be possible," says Leonard.

In the future, the researchers hope to test their hypothesis that lyrebirds reduce fire risk in a controlled burn.

Meanwhile, they are also studying malleefowl, which could also perform a similar function in the bush, says Leonard.

urn:contentItem:56TJ-6111-JD3N-53K5-00000-00A PROVINCIAL VIEW Corporate forests a fire issue2012-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 32A PROVINCIAL VIEW Corporate forests a fire issueBARNEY McCUSKER

(NB: South East page - corresponding hard copy not available to Editorial Library)

BUSHFIRES are a constant Sword of Damocles hanging over the communities of South East South Australia.

In speaking to a number of experts in the fire fighting industry, there are some fundamental facts they agree on.

Each year there will be six to 10 extreme fire days and this is only going to get worse with the passing decades.

We have already seen some examples in our lifetime. First, in 1983 with Ash Wednesday, which was associated with considerable loss of life and again in 2004, with the Wandilo fire, it was a case of every hand to the pumps.

There have been other close-run days over those years and there will be more.

Currently we have 12 Fire King fire trucks, four in each of three localities under the control of Forestry SA.

Supporting these 12 Fire Kings are 23 CFS units spread across the South-East from places like Tantanoola, Beachport, Furner, Mount McIntyre and Mount Burr - 19 stations in all.

These 23 CFS units are all manned by volunteers with the support of government funding and it is frightening to think what would have happened on those bad fire days if we hadn't had these volunteer fire units.

Of course that was then, when the forests of Forestry SA were owned by the people of South Australia.

Now those state forests will soon be under the control of a private corporation run from overseas and for the benefit of overseas investors. This will be the case for the next 105 years.

The question that this community must now ask ourselves is whether we can ask these volunteer firefighters to put themselves in the path of danger, as they have in the past, to help quell fires in a privately owned forest?

I have asked a number of people engaged in the fire-fighting profession and no one can give me an answer but the general impression is that you can hardly ask a volunteer to go and fight a forest fire in a privately owned forest.

Those who I have spoken to do not believe this issue has been resolved by our government and I think it needs addressing as we are coming into another fire season.

Barney McCusker is a Mt Gambier orthopaedic surgeon

urn:contentItem:54X8-W3G1-JD34-V1N0-00000-00Firefighter gets in on the ground floor2011-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisCLASSIFIEDPg. 48Firefighter gets in on the ground floor

Ashley Miller, a firefighter who loves the Aussie outdoors, talks with Rebecca Miller

What I do: I work for the Department of Sustainability and Environment as a firefighter, preventing and responding to fires on public land. I'm learning to operate plant machinery to prevent fires spreading. I have always been part of the ground firefighter crew, training and remaining on standby to respond to fires. I work with a rake hoe crew felling dangerous trees and driving a 4WD with many litres of water, and am part of the crew on a fire tanker. I am involved with care and maintenance of recreation walking tracks, campsites and historical and environmental areas of significance.

How I got here: I studied natural resource management at TAFE. During work placement in state parks, I met forest-fire crews and decided to build a career. I began as a seasonal project firefighter then moved into managing project firefighters and fire recovery program contracts and on to what I do now.

My typical week: Each unique week involves keeping fit, forest patrols, training, maintenance of fuel breaks, roads/tracks and fire equipment. From chainsawing after a wind storm or flying in a helicopter over rugged bush terrain to work on controlling lightning strike damage, my work is very diverse. I also maintain fire pumps or climb fire towers as a fire spotter.

The good bits: I like being able to work in the great Australian outdoors. I enjoy the variety in my role as each day is different. The team I work with is great and we have a strong sense of camaraderie.

Work stress: There's plenty of paperwork, which can be painstaking and stressful to complete, but it has to be done. Obtaining all the facts and information is imperative. Generally, I tend not to let things stress me out at work.

How I relax: During the week, I enjoy going jogging after work with my dog or listening to my iPod. On weekends, I like seeing a live band with mates and unwinding with a drink.

The next step: I plan to continue operating machinery and training. I look forward to gaining more experience, mentoring crew members and managing larger-scale incidents.

urn:contentItem:5VW5-CF51-JCM0-600X-00000-00Beyond the blaze: Behind the scenes of Australia's big fires2019-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisBeyond the blaze: Behind the scenes of Australia's big firesBy Danielle Bonica and Rachel Carbonell

In 2019, the ABC went behind the scenes to follow Victorian firefighters as they cleaned up following destructive bushfires at Bunyip, in West Gippsland.

The footy oval at Nar Nar Goon just east of Melbourne is all lit up and abuzz with activity.

The stakes are high, but there's no game on tonight.

The ground has been transformed into an emergency staging area in the battle against the nearby Bunyip bushfire.

Exhausted firefighters are rolling in by the truckload, resting where they can, slumped against walls and sprawled on the grass.

The fire broke out at the tail end of another scorching Australian bushfire season.

It menaced communities on Melbourne's fringe, burning 15,400 hectares, 29 houses and 69 sheds.

Like all the fires before it, when the flames died down, so did the headlines.

When the flames die down but the danger doesn't

But bushfires don't just suddenly "go out". When they're brought under control, weeks of tireless mopping-up begins.

It's early morning and Andy Beckett is meeting clean-up crews on the side of the road to triage the day's jobs.

He's with the Forest Fire Management division of the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning.

"Houses don't burn down just during the fire, they burn down after," he says.

Andy says while the fire is no longer actively threatening homes, critical work remains to keep people safe.

As if to prove his point, a thick plume of smoke suddenly erupts on a property behind him.

Within seconds CFA trucks are on their way up the small track and a water-bombing helicopter is sent in.

"I'm surmising but possibly a shed might have been already damaged," he says.

"Something has been burning in the corner of it and it has just taken off."

Andy knows from experience that fresh fires igniting days after the blaze are part of the clean-up process.

"And this is a classic [case] of that now." he says.

Trees can be killers

Rattled locals are desperate to get back to their homes.

"[We're] just opening up the priority roads so that we can open it up to the essential services and the residents again," Andy says.

Burnt trees are the most immediate and dangerous challenge. They can be unstable and unpredictable. And they can be killers.

Not only can they suddenly come down, but if a tree is smouldering it can spark another bushfire.

Dry weather and wind will ignite the sleepiest of embers.

The spider making short work of burnt trees

In an Australian first, this crew is using a new model of machinery to help remove those dangerous trees.

It's a giant machine perched on wheeled legs with a grapple and a chainsaw.

"It's a spider excavator. You can tell by its legs that's what it gets its name from," Andy says.

It is operated by remote control, moving into tricky spots without putting the crew in harm's way.

"It's a pretty cool machine," he said.

"[It] can reach and grab dangerous trees, cut them off and put them on the ground, all very safely."

Limb by limb it clambers up the dirt road. Within a few moments it clears what would have taken humans hours to do.

With the spider's help a 115-kilometre stretch of road has been cleared on both sides.

Saving precious habitat trees

Big bushfires can take out critically important habitat trees, making it even harder for surviving wildlife to shelter and survive.

While most risky trees are cut down, crews try their best to save environmentally significant trees wherever they can.

A call comes through on the two-way radio about a grand old tree smouldering up the road.

Mick Anzin is the chainsaw operator for the day.

He gives it the critical once-over.

"It seems pretty healthy, so we try to save as many trees as we can," he said.

"I can feel and see how far the fire has actually gone up the trunk."

Foam and water is sprayed on to the tree.

Then Mick Anzin cuts a crevice into the base, then Andy Beckett steps in with a shovel to dig the coals out.

This process of spray-cut-dig continues until the heat is removed without damaging the tree structure.

It's time-consuming, but rewarding.

Andy puts the shovel down.

"With any luck that tree will stand for a long while yet," he says.

Unseen heat, the invisible threat

Falling trees are an obvious risk. Some of the other post-fire hazards are trickier to spot.

Unseen hotspots can turn into fresh fire breakouts in an instant.

New technology is now helping to locate these hotspots.

At night, thermal imaging cameras are used from the air to pinpoint where they are, and then they're hit with water-bombing helicopters.

During the day, temperature indicator cameras see what the naked eye cannot and read the ground temperature.

Any reading over 50 degrees has the potential to spark a new flare-up.

Scorched earth

During today's operation, burnt, grey and benign-looking paddocks are being scanned for problematic patches.

Suddenly a reading of 500 degrees pops up on the camera.

It's the remains of a big haystack that has been smouldering for days.

CFA Strike team leader Peter Cattermole and his crew get to work to make sure the hidden embers here don't cause a flare-up.

"We bring the trucks in and they'll wet all of this area down here and cool it right down," he said.

"Then they'll put a cover of foam over it to try to seal it and stop it going in to the paddock there."

Only when there is a decent rainfall, will the fires be truly out.

CFA member Roy Wilding is working as deputy on this shift.

He's frustrated that it's such slow work and he's worried about farmers who are still stuck without power.

"We wanted to get all the main services in, the power back in, the water back in because a lot of the farmers around here require the power to power their pumps."

Without electricity, it can be hard to care for stock properly.

"We had farmers that hadn't milked cows for two days," he said.

"The poor girls, they're bursting at the seams dripping milk everywhere."

Volunteering after the blaze

The mop-up is far less glamorous than fighting the blaze when it's out of control, when lives are in danger and the cameras are rolling.

Assistant chief fire officer with the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Chris Eagle, says the work can continue for many weeks and can start to feel boring and relentless.

"It's one of the things ... the job seems monotonous but it's actually important and it's a critical part of the fire."

"They will spend ten hours out in the fire ground and a lot of it might be driving up and down the road patrolling, and they will do nothing else but patrol."

While department staff are all paid, the CFA clean-up crews rely on a core of volunteers.

Chris Eagle says employers can more easily justify releasing staff to volunteer when the fire is making big news.

But he says, come clean-up time, it becomes harder to get volunteers because the work doesn't appear as urgent.

"So we actually make sure our staff and volunteers know whilst the job they are doing seems monotonous, it's actually important and it's a critical part of the fire."

One fire family

Keeping track of the team's work is Bec Johns. She is penciller for the day. Her job is to keep a record of everything the crew is doing.

Bec joined the CFA juniors at the age of 11, and is a fourth-generation CFA volunteer.

Today is a nice break after a few intense days battling to bring the blaze under control.

Her father and grandfather were also fighting the fire.

"We always find each other, we have a family reunion out in the fire ground ... I'm pretty proud," she said.

Bec is just one of the army of volunteers who work for weeks and months after the hundreds of bushfires each year in Australia.

Without them and the paid crews that work alongside them, the aftermath of Australia's bushfire season would be a lot worse.

Foam and water is sprayed on to the tree.

Then Mick Anzin cuts a crevice into the base, then Andy Beckett steps in with a shovel to dig the coals out.

This process of spray-cut-dig continues until the heat is removed without damaging the tree structure.

It's time-consuming, but rewarding.

Andy puts the shovel down.

"With any luck that tree will stand for a long while yet," he says.

Unseen heat, the invisible threat

Falling trees are an obvious risk. Some of the other post-fire hazards are trickier to spot.

Unseen hotspots can turn into fresh fire breakouts in an instant.

New technology is now helping to locate these hotspots.

At night, thermal imaging cameras are used from the air to pinpoint where they are, and then they're hit with water-bombing helicopters.

During the day, temperature indicator cameras see what the naked eye cannot and read the ground temperature.

Any reading over 50 degrees has the potential to spark a new flare-up.

Scorched earth

During today's operation, burnt, grey and benign-looking paddocks are being scanned for problematic patches.

Suddenly a reading of 500 degrees pops up on the camera.

It's the remains of a big haystack that has been smouldering for days.

CFA Strike team leader Peter Cattermole and his crew get to work to make sure the hidden embers here don't cause a flare-up.

"We bring the trucks in and they'll wet all of this area down here and cool it right down," he said.

"Then they'll put a cover of foam over it to try to seal it and stop it going in to the paddock there."

Only when there is a decent rainfall, will the fires be truly out.

CFA member Roy Wilding is working as deputy on this shift.

He's frustrated that it's such slow work and he's worried about farmers who are still stuck without power.

"We wanted to get all the main services in, the power back in, the water back in because a lot of the farmers around here require the power to power their pumps."

Without electricity, it can be hard to care for stock properly.

"We had farmers that hadn't milked cows for two days," he said.

"The poor girls, they're bursting at the seams dripping milk everywhere."

Volunteering after the blaze

The mop-up is far less glamorous than fighting the blaze when it's out of control, when lives are in danger and the cameras are rolling.

Assistant chief fire officer with the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Chris Eagle, says the work can continue for many weeks and can start to feel boring and relentless.

"It's one of the things ... the job seems monotonous but it's actually important and it's a critical part of the fire."

"They will spend ten hours out in the fire ground and a lot of it might be driving up and down the road patrolling, and they will do nothing else but patrol."

While department staff are all paid, the CFA clean-up crews rely on a core of volunteers.

Chris Eagle says employers can more easily justify releasing staff to volunteer when the fire is making big news.

But he says, come clean-up time, it becomes harder to get volunteers because the work doesn't appear as urgent.

"So we actually make sure our staff and volunteers know whilst the job they are doing seems monotonous, it's actually important and it's a critical part of the fire."

One fire family

Keeping track of the team's work is Bec Johns. She is penciller for the day. Her job is to keep a record of everything the crew is doing.

Bec joined the CFA juniors at the age of 11, and is a fourth-generation CFA volunteer.

Today is a nice break after a few intense days battling to bring the blaze under control.

Her father and grandfather were also fighting the fire.

"We always find each other, we have a family reunion out in the fire ground ... I'm pretty proud," she said.

Bec is just one of the army of volunteers who work for weeks and months after the hundreds of bushfires each year in Australia.

Without them and the paid crews that work alongside them, the aftermath of Australia's bushfire season would be a lot worse.

urn:contentItem:56KT-FJM1-F0JP-W20G-00000-00Fears of arsonist behind bushfires2012-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisPg. 2Fears of arsonist behind bushfiresNIKKI TODD

TWEED EDITION

AUTHORITIES fear a firebug has set up on the Tweed coast, with at least four blazes in the past week, including a major bushfire at Kings Forest, now considered suspicious.

More than 40 firefighters from the Rural Fire Service and Fire and Rescue NSW were called to tackle a major bushfire that burned through 95ha of land at Kings Forest and Cudgen Nature Reserve last Friday.

Firefighters were kept busy across the weekend after another blaze broke out on the eastern side of Tweed Coast Rd near Salt on Saturday and another at Fingal Head later that afternoon.

The fires followed a smaller blaze in the dunes at Cabarita earlier in the week, with investigators now considering all may have been deliberately lit.

RFS Far North Coast team manager Superintendent David Cook said an investigation involving fire authorities and police had begun.

``It appears to be suspicious, that is all I can say at this stage - there is no other possible reason why the fire was caused,'' Supt Cook said.

``We will know a bit more in a few days. We are working with police but we can't get into the fire area with our specialist investigators yet.''

Supt Cook said he had taken the first call about the Kings Forest fire too early for the sun to have played a role.

``I got the call to it at 5.30am on Friday morning,'' he said yesterday.

``Earlier in the week we had another fire in the dunes down at Cabarita that started for no apparent reason as well.

``We are flat out but we have got them all contained and so far today things have been quiet.''

Tweed Byron police crime manager Acting Inspector Saul Wiseman said a criminal detective had been assigned to investigate the fires but it was still too early to make a call on whether they were the act of an arsonist or not.

``We haven't any indication at the moment as to what has caused this fire,'' he said.

Insp Wiseman said the case would be referred to Strike Force Tronto, an ongoing taskforce set up to investigate deliberately lit bushfires in NSW.

Meanwhile a NSW Parks and Wildlife spokesman said rangers had not yet found any evidence of injured wildlife from the fire at Cudgen Paddock.

Anyone with information about the fires can call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:54X8-W3G1-JD34-V23H-00000-00Firefighter gets in on the ground floor2011-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisCLASSIFIEDPg. 99Firefighter gets in on the ground floor

Ashley Miller, a firefighter who loves the Aussie outdoors, talks with Rebecca Miller

What I do: I work for the Department of Sustainability and Environment as a firefighter, preventing and responding to fires on public land. I'm learning to operate plant machinery to prevent fires spreading. I have always been part of the ground firefighter crew, training and remaining on standby to respond to fires. I work with a rake hoe crew felling dangerous trees and driving a 4WD with many litres of water, and am part of the crew on a fire tanker. I am involved with care and maintenance of recreation walking tracks, campsites and historical and environmental areas of significance.

How I got here: I studied natural resource management at TAFE. During work placement in state parks, I met forest-fire crews and decided to build a career. I began as a seasonal project firefighter then moved into managing project firefighters and fire recovery program contracts and on to what I do now.

My typical week: Each unique week involves keeping fit, forest patrols, training, maintenance of fuel breaks, roads/tracks and fire equipment. From chainsawing after a wind storm or flying in a helicopter over rugged bush terrain to work on controlling lightning strike damage, my work is very diverse. I also maintain fire pumps or climb fire towers as a fire spotter.

The good bits: I like being able to work in the great Australian outdoors. I enjoy the variety in my role as each day is different. The team I work with is great and we have a strong sense of camaraderie.

Work stress: There's plenty of paperwork, which can be painstaking and stressful to complete, but it has to be done. Obtaining all the facts and information is imperative. Generally, I tend not to let things stress me out at work.

How I relax: During the week, I enjoy going jogging after work with my dog or listening to my iPod. On weekends, I like seeing a live band with mates and unwinding with a drink.

The next step: I plan to continue operating machinery and training. I look forward to gaining more experience, mentoring crew members and managing larger-scale incidents.

urn:contentItem:54FS-9H01-JD67-12WP-00000-00City warned of high fire risk2011-12-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5City warned of high fire riskBRAD WORRALL

WODONGA and Baranduda are among 12 North East towns singled out as at risk from wild fires this summer. CFA protection plans that will be delivered to homes from today rate the danger for Wodonga as high to very high. While those in the valleys face the threat from the heavily timbered national parks, it suggests grass fires and bushfires on the urban fringe pose the greatest danger to the city.

Maps of Wodonga also show the potential for green belts to carry fires into the heart of the city's residential areas. The hard-hitting message from the CFA warns that not every home can be protected. Baranduda is highlighted as being at high risk from both grass and forest fires. The CFA protection plan also said the residential area is exposed to ember attacks during a bushfire. The plan also shows five of the high-risk towns have no sanctuary for people whose own bushfire plan has failed. Glenrowan and Mitta are the only North East towns rated as extreme fire risks. The speed of a forest fire is said to be the greatest threat to Mitta, while the Warby-Ovens National Park poses the greatest danger to Glenrowan and the nearby Wangaratta suburb of Hamilton Park. CFA Hume regional manager Alan Davies said the plans had been developed in consultation with local communities, councils, brigades and various government agencies for people who are in areas most at risk of bushfire or grass fire this summer. "Township protection plans will help locals and visitors identify important community assets, primary roads to exit the area, where to go, survival options and important emergency contact information," he said. Mr Davies said the plans will be going out to every home in the target communities as part of a mail-out to 400,000 addresses across Victoria. "Bushfire and grass fire are an ever-present danger in these townships and all are classified as having a bushfire risk of very high or extreme," he said. "Now is the time to start preparing. "The township protection plan is one piece of paper that every family in a high risk area should have up on their fridge."

urn:contentItem:5GBY-G1K1-F0J6-J128-00000-007 DAYS2015-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWS REVIEWPg. 287 DAYSDAMIEN MURPHY on what whetted our presses this week

Good week

Protection money

The mafia was exposed donating $51,000 to the NSW Liberal Party fundraiser, the Millennium Forum, to have an Italian thug with a lengthy record remain in Australia.

Both well

A Californian woman who gave birth alone and was stranded for days in a remote area started a forest fire that attracted firefighters to her rescue.

Gardening notes

Dame Marie Bashir, former NSW governor and former patron of the Rose Society of NSW, had a rose named in her honour.

Bad week

Dental hygiene

NSW health authorities fear 11,000 patients from two Sydney dental clinics could have been exposed to HIV and hepatitis because of poor cleaning and equipment sterilisation.

Marlboro men

Three hundred Victorian prisoners rioted over moves to ban smoking in jail.

Union busting

The former Health Services Union national secretary Kathy Jackson declared herself bankrupt on the eve of her two-week trial for alleged misuse of more than $1.4 million in members' funds.

Lleyton Hewitt exits final Wimbledon

smh.com.au, June 30

Australian golfer Adam Scott has given close friend Lleyton Hewitt a glowing tribute after the veteran's Wimbledon swansong ended in heartbreak on Monday. Hewitt put in a typical fighting performance in a marathon five-set match against Finland's Jarkko Nieminen, going down 3-6, 6-3, 4-6, 6-0, 11-9. Scott, who asked by Hewitt to watch him while he was in Britain preparing for next month's British Open, described the 34-year-old as an inspiration. Hewitt finishes his Wimbledon career equal with Roger Federer with the most appearances (17) at The All England Club.

16.5 million

The number of Jewish people across the world has reportedly reached pre-Holocaust levels. The Jewish People Policy Institute in Jerusalem said there were currently 14.2 million Jews but arrived at the higher estimate by factoring in people with one Jewish parent who identified as partially Jewish.

Martin to audit Q&A after terrorism furore

smh.com.au, July 1

The ABC has appointed television veteran Ray Martin to conduct an audit of Q&A, which has been mired in controversy after it invited former terror suspect Zaky Mallah to ask a question live on air. The ABC board also announced that the program's executive producer, Peter McEvoy, has received a formal warning for misconduct. The editorial audit, which is independent of the ABC, will be an examination of Q&A's selection of topics and panelists this year. It will also examine the way audiences are selected and the use of tweets on air.

52,786

Number of Westminster accesses to a website that allows visitors to pick the sexiest English MP. An FOI request revealed sexymp.co.uk, despite filters, was the most popular banned website in the Houses of Parliament.

Employee who abused bosses unfairly sacked

The Sydney Morning Herald, July 3

An employee who sexually harassed colleagues and told his bosses to f--- off at a Christmas party was unfairly sacked partly because the company had supplied him with alcohol, the Fair Work Commission has found. Employers may not be in a position to insist on standards of conduct at functions if they serve unlimited amounts of alcohol, the commission found. It was told a male employee at Leighton Boral Amey Joint Venture drank about 10 beers and one vodka and coke, plus two stubbies before he arrived. Commission vice-president Adam Hatcher said the employee's conduct was the result of his intoxication.

61 seconds

Time of the final "minute" of Tuesday, June 30. Since 1972 the "leap second" has been inserted every few years to ensure the atomic time stays aligned with the earth's rotation rates.

urn:contentItem:51TW-S6W1-JCM0-61SX-00000-00Wet weather fails to extinguish wildfire risk2010-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisWet weather fails to extinguish wildfire riskGordon Taylor

The Canberra region is facing further flooding with the current La Nina weather pattern expected to produce more severe thunderstorms over the rest of summer.

But the predicted wet weather is not diminishing the threat of wildfires in the grasses that have grown prolifically over the past few months.

"The risk of grassfires is increasing because the grass curing rates are now increasing. We're seeing curing rates of 60 to 70 per cent and we're seeing extensive grasslands right across south eastern New South Wales," said ACT Emergency Services Commissioner Mark Crosweller.

"That's unusual, we haven't seen this much grass in perhaps 20 to 25 years.

"We're not dealing so much with a forest fire problem this summer as we are with a grassfire problem."

The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting the high temperatures needed to dry out the grasses.

"We should hit at least 35 degrees in the next week, comparing that to the last few years where we hit 40 degrees by even the 1st of December," said forecaster Sean Carson.

"So it's still hot but it's certainly not as hot as we've experienced in the last few years, but you never get through a summer in Canberra without getting some hot days."

The wildfire threat may not be the only headache this summer with Australia experiencing a strong La Nina event that has brought the rains .

The wet weather has filled dams and saturated the soil, leaving the landscaped primed for further flooding.

"Every dam is full, public and private, so all of our reservoirs are now 100 per cent, all our private farm dams are 100 per cent and soil moistures are very high," Mr Crosweller said.

"The land can't take much more water so any rainfall that we see during this summer time will be principally watershed or run-off straight into our creeks and tributaries so there's an increased capacity for flooding across the landscape."

The Bureau of Meteorology says the La Nina event and the threat of flooding will continue until at least mid-February.

urn:contentItem:5HCY-SKG1-F031-X42V-00000-00The catastrophe of Indonesia's forest fires2015-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisScience Show5:03 PM AESTThe catastrophe of Indonesia's forest fires

Robyn Williams:This week the Prime Minister visited Indonesia, and one topic he may have discussed behind closed doors is fire, because Indonesia is burning, catastrophically, and this is once more choking neighbouring countries. Brendan May chairs Robertsbridge, which works extensively on deforestation in our region.

Brendan May:Indonesia's forest fires are a catastrophe, not just regionally but globally. Over 8,000 square miles of forest and peatland have been burnt to a crisp. That's an area 12 times bigger than Sydney and 30 times bigger than Indonesia's smog suffering neighbour Singapore. And with the losses of forest and peat come other calamities; a devastating wipe-out of habitat and already endangered wildlife, a humanitarian disaster with half a million people suffering from respiratory complaints and 19 dead, and a simply staggering increase in greenhouse gas emissions, rivalling the annual total emissions of many industrialised countries.

And right now the world is focused on the COP21 climate talks in Paris, designed for the first time to deliver legally binding limits, country by country, on emissions in order to avoid global average temperatures rising more than a further two degrees. Arguably, recent events in Indonesia have already made a significant contribution to disabling this process. It is INDC's (a clumsy UN acronym for Intended Nationally Determined Contributions) call for a 26% emissions reduction by 2020 and a conditional 41% by 2030, assuming international support. This is all using 2010 as a business-as-usual baseline.

Forestry, including fires, has contributed 60% of the country's total emissions over the last decade. Indonesia is also rich in coal and is developing new coal-fired power stations to meet increasing energy demand, and much of that coal of course lies beneath forest cover. And the most readily available source of biofuel feedstock (another growth area) is from, guess where, forestry. So whichever way you look at it, forestry is the elephant in the room.

But we need to look very carefully at the causes of these devastating fires and the resulting pollution. Unique to Indonesia is the fact that much of the country's forest sits on colossally deep peatland which, when it's cleared and drained, burns for a very, very long time if ignited. Once alight, peat emits all the CO2 it has stored over the millennia that it took to create.

That peatland has been drained in the first place does lie at the door of the big forestry businesses in Indonesia, largely palm oil and pulp plantation concession owners. But some of the biggest players have undergone a radical transformation and imposed zero deforestation policies across huge swathes of the landscape, and they've stopped developing on peatland. That has been one of the most positive news stories to come out of the environment movement in recent years.

The most sophisticated measures being taken by companies in Indonesia include the retirement of plantations on peat, complex management regimes to secure the forested and peatland landscapes, and to restore and conserve sufficient areas to address their legacies of destruction. All this is unprecedented progress. These companies now rely entirely on the plantations that already exist, so it's clearly not in their interests to set fire to their own raw material supply. Blaming fires on very large companies may be headline grabbing, but it's missing the point and it's wildly inaccurate. In fact the companies themselves are deploying thousands of firefighters to protect their assets.

The causal truth is very complex. It starts with the uncomfortable fact that there is very little clear definition over who actually owns what land. Commercial concessions in Indonesia often overlap with each other, and indigenous communities claim (often but not always legitimately) that they have a historic right to the use of traditionally held lands. Corruption and lawbreaking are endemic, policing is weak, and illegal encroachment is widespread.

Forest fire is an organised criminal industry. Much has been written and spoken about this. Fingers have been pointed, accusations hurled around the ether. But what the world needs to do now is to focus not simply on the cause and effect of forest fire but the cure. My own feeling is that this cure has three core elements. First, and most obviously, political. The current President of Indonesia, Joko Widodo, or Jokowi as he is popularly known, is the first President not to emerge from the country's ruling elite or military, and as such he heads a government with a populist leaning agenda. But he also has to wrestle with a legacy of deeply entrenched self-interest, widespread corruption, particularly at regional and local level, and a historically unhealthy link between business and politics. His is an extremely difficult balancing act. And to be fair, he has taken some action, not least returning early from a visit to America to deal with the crisis. The President has ordered a moratorium on new licences to develop peatland, and he has ordered officials to prosecute those who clear land by burning.

But his own populism can work against him too. He is considering an electoral promise to redistribute some 9 million hectares of land to farmers, raising their average landholding from 0.8 to 2 hectares. Coupled with that, not all forest fires are started illegally. Whilst enforcement may be feeble and it's illegal for companies to start fires for clearance, there are instances where small holders can do so. It is the cheapest way of clearing land. Put the two together and you can guess the result.

What Jokowi needs is not sanctimonious words from the rest of the world's political leadership, he needs help. First he needs the Paris climate talks to deliver tangible solutions that could be translated into practical policy back home, so that Indonesia can carry back the legitimacy to enact a legal framework that enables compliance with the agreements coming out of Paris. Permanent and well policed bans on any natural forest and peatland clearance of any sort by anyone, for example.

Second, he needs the support of politically derived institutions, US aid for example. And in particular the Norwegians who through their gigantic sovereign wealth finance can fund many of the compensatory initiatives that are needed to enable smallholder farmers to earn a living without burning forests, and which can also help in the hugely complex and expensive task of blocking canals, rewetting peatlands and reforestation. And of course countries like Australia, which sadly has had much experience of forest fires of its own.

The second part of the cure is commercial, and I should declare an interest here, I have worked with very large Indonesian businesses on zero deforestation initiatives for some years, and I know what challenges they face. And by the way, none of them are perfect. But I also know that with will and investment and leadership, it can be done. So the outside world of business needs to sit up and take more notice of those companies that can genuinely prove they have eliminated deforestation in their supply chains and have taken real steps to dealing with their legacy through conservation and restoration and who are making the right investments in communities across their concessions that help them avoid the need to clear land to make a living.

And this outside world of business needs also to move faster and further in making its own supply chain fully responsible. There are some shining lights here, ones you might not even expect, like Nestlé and Ferrero chocolate. But there are some real laggards. Why is PepsiCo being coy about deforestation? Why is Kraft Heinz equally flaccid on the subject? What kind of message does this timid approach from some consumer goods companies send?

The third cure lies in the hands of the environmental campaigning NGOs. With some notable exception, it seems to me that they are remarkably dysfunctional. Many of them have fallen into the trap of thinking that if they lose the object of their protest, then they have no raison d'être, so they continue to protest, even if the evidence is clear that they have won, and they should be supporting companies who are progressive and trying to change. There will always be other targets.

In the end of course the fires will go out, and at last some rain has arrived, but too often, once the haze clears, attention drifts elsewhere too. This time perhaps it will be different because of the sheer scale of the disaster. We must hope so, for Indonesia's sake and the world's future.

Robyn Williams: Brendan May chairs Robertsbridge, based in England. And as you heard, it does lots of work in Indonesia.

urn:contentItem:54VK-58K1-F0J6-J2MS-00000-00Firefighter gets in on the ground floor2011-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisCLASSIFIEDPg. 79Firefighter gets in on the ground floor

Ashley Miller, a firefighter who loves the Aussie outdoors, talks with Rebecca Miller What I do: I work for the Department of Sustainability and Environment as a firefighter, preventing and responding to fires on public land. I'm learning to operate plant machinery to prevent fires spreading. I have always been part of the ground firefighter crew, training and remaining on standby to respond to fires.

I work with a rake hoe crew felling dangerous trees and driving a 4WD with many litres of water, and am part of the crew on a fire tanker. I am involved with care and maintenance of recreation walking tracks, campsites and historical and environmental areas of significance. How I got here: I studied natural resource management at TAFE. During work placement in state parks, I met forest-fire crews and decided to build a career. I began as a seasonal project firefighter then moved into managing project firefighters and fire recovery program contracts and on to what I do now. My typical week: Each unique week involves keeping fit, forest patrols, training, maintenance of fuel breaks, roads/tracks and fire equipment. From chainsawing after a wind storm or flying in a helicopter over rugged bush terrain to work on controlling lightning strike damage, my work is very diverse. I also maintain fire pumps or climb fire towers as a fire spotter. The good bits: I like being able to work in the great Australian outdoors. I enjoy the variety in my role as each day is different. The team I work with is great and we have a strong sense of camaraderie. Work stress: There's plenty of paperwork, which can be painstaking and stressful to complete, but it has to be done. Obtaining all the facts and information is imperative. Generally, I tend not to let things stress me out at work. How I relax: During the week, I enjoy going jogging after work with my dog or listening to my iPod. On weekends, I like seeing a live band with mates and unwinding with a drink. The next step: I plan to continue operating machinery and training. I look forward to gaining more experience, mentoring crew members and managing larger-scale incidents.

urn:contentItem:4J42-Y270-TX5K-W29G-00000-00Grass fire puts2006-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Grass fire putshomes at riskat Kinglake

HOMES were under threat as an out-of-control forest fire raged through Kinglake National Park on Monday morning.

Kinglake residents who chose to stay with their homes were warned to watch for embers and wear protective clothing as 117 firefighters in 28 CFA trucks worked with Department of Sustainability and Environment crews to contain the blaze.

Residents around Captains Creek Rd, about 3km south-west of Glenburn, were told to put their fire plans into action after lightning strikes and searing temperatures sparked a fire shortly after noon last Sunday.

The fire broke out near Boggy Creek, about 14km north of Kinglake, but south-easterly winds caused it to cross Candlebark Track and turn towards Captains Creek Rd.

Fire crews used five bulldozers at Burgen Creek in the Kinglake National Park to build earth fire breaks on either side of the blaze, which had burnt through 300ha by 3.25am.

By Monday air support was needed to slow the spread of the fire and support ground crews, CFA spokesman Clifford Overton said.

Lightning and hot temperatures over the weekend resulted in several fires throughout Nillumbik.

Region 13 fire crews also worked throughout Saturday to contain grass fires at Rifle Range Reserve in Smiths Gully and in Steels Creek Rd, Yarra Glen.

* For information on fires, call the Victorian Bushfire Information Line on 1800 240 667.

urn:contentItem:548S-1F51-F0JP-W541-00000-00Grass fire our great risk: CFA2011-11-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Grass fire our great risk: CFAVICTORIA MacDONALD

RAPIDLY spreading grass fires pose the biggest risk in the Geelong region this summer, emergency chiefs have warned.

Previewing the state's fire season in Melbourne yesterday, CFA chief officer Euan Ferguson said a grass fire under extreme or Code Red conditions would burn about 25km/h two to three times as fast as a forest fire.

``If you're in rural Victoria and a fire starts 15km away from you, in 30 minutes it could be where you are,'' he said.

``The fire, which is a distant smoke right now, in 30 minutes could be engulfing you.''

Mr Ferguson said heavy rain this year had contributed to the fast growth of grass, which is now drying out. He said after years of drought, residents might not be familiar with the pace at which grassland fires could spread.

Contributing to the region's fire risk, Bureau of Meteorology acting regional director Ted Williams said the seasonal outlook for December to February indicated below average rainfall in the southwest of Victoria.

Temperatures across the state are also expected to be warmer than average.

CFA Barwon South West commander John Mealia said all residents had a responsibility to prepare a survival plan in advance, while the onus was also on the region's landowners to ensure their properties didn't contain heavy fuel loads.

Mr Mealia said as well as encouraging residents to beware of fire risks, informing tourists also posed a challenge for the region's emergency services.

``I've purposely travelled the Great Ocean Road on a Code Red day in the morning and it's absolutely chock-a-block,'' he said.

``There's those leaving Ocean Road, which is people leaving early, and all the tourists going in.

``There's an enormous misunderstanding of risk by the tourists.''

While the region's police and other emergency services have developed bushfire evacuation procedures including a drill to be held today in the Otways at Lavers Hill Mr Mealia said evacuations were unlikely to be used in a grassfire situation, due to the pace of the fire.

Mr Mealia also said in the event of an evacuation, residents would be notified through alert systems and emergency broadcasters.

victoria.macdonald@geelongadvertiser.com.au

urn:contentItem:51W0-T6H1-JD3N-5041-00000-00Kept in the dark2011-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisEGNPg. 3Kept in the darkPETER HUNT

Public denied access to bureau's fire-weather website

THE Bureau of Meteorology has locked the public out of its main fire-weather website.

Only registered users can gain access to the bureau's fire weather web pages, which contain crucial four-day forecasts on grassland and forest-fire danger indices.

The pages even contain maps showing the level of grassland curing across the state, spot-fire and prescribed burn forecasts, plus tables showing a raft of fire-related weather forecasts for each district.

The bureau's services policy branch manager, Robin Hicks, said the site was restricted to ``registered users'' in a bid to avoid public confusion.

But former bureau supervisory meteorologist for fire weather services David Packham said it was absurd to restrict community access to the site.

``It's the best fire-weather information in Australia, it's paid for by the public and the public needs that information,'' Mr Packham said.

``People are quite capable of interpreting this information.

``It's part of the education process in understanding fire weather, which volunteer (firefighters) need to understand.''

But Mr Hicks said some of the information on the fire-weather page was in development and needed to be interpreted in the right way, which was why it was generally restricted to fire-agency and government staff.

But Mr Packham said the bureau already gave the public access to complex weather forecasts and climatic information that was ``in development''.

``People are intelligent, especially rural people, when it comes to weather,'' Mr Packham said.

``I think it's got more to do with the CFA and DSE (Department of Sustainability and Environment) wanting to maintain control of all (fire weather information), which the bureau has always gone along with.''

It's not the first time Australian climate scientists have called for forecast information to be withheld from the public.

In 2007, The Weekly Times reported Australian climate scientists had urged their Japanese colleagues to keep a forecast of continuing drought under wraps as it would be ``very upsetting to the public who live in areas of risk''.
