urn:contentItem:5RXY-F161-JD34-V4CX-00000-00Time to put Lake Burrumbeet back on the agenda say activists2018-03-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisSATURDAYTime to put Lake Burrumbeet back on the agenda say activistsGreg Gliddon

IT'S only eight minutes from the heart of Ballarat, but Lake Burrumbeet has become the forgotten jewel in the region's crown.

Despite being a world class area for wildlife and birdlife, the Friends of the Lake group and the traditional Indigenous owners believe for too long it has been left to rot, becoming a haven for antisocial behaviour and litter.

The Friends of the Lake Burrumbeet say it is time to start looking after one of the few natural wildernesses left in the western district.

"We want it to be a world class area for wildlife which is connected with birdlife," Friends of Lake Burrumbeet spokeswoman Susan Moodie said.

"It is home to 13 species of bat, it used to have eel, there used to be platypus, there are still some turtles around."

"We want to celebrate cultural diversity with joint signage and interpretations about what makes this place so unique in the world. That's what draws tourists. That's what people want to know.

"We need to say why it is important and the facilities need to reflect the beauty of the place."

Ms Moodie said since the City of Ballarat handed the responsibility of the lake to the state, "the management has been shocking".

"There have been three management plans, the first in 1986. None have been implemented," she said.

"Ballarat ceded its responsibility, its bylaws and oversight to the state. The decline in services has been unfortunate for visitors and the ecology of this reserve."

The problems at the lake were brought to stark realisation when anti-social behaviour at the campgrounds over the Australia Day long weekend turned a number of locals and campers away from the site.

Incidents including hooning, public drunkenness, extreme littering, and a dog attack all occurred in the space of a few days at the lake's campgrounds.

A camper who spoke to The Courier after the weekend said dangerous behaviour and fighting ruined the trip.

"We went to bed at about 10pm and the at about 2am a car, don't know how fast, flew along the dirt road and then there were two more cars possibly chasing it," she said.

"There were kids asleep in tents and swags everywhere and I was really worried."

She said she could hear people fighting all night and spent her night worried for her family's safety.

"It was feral, there was a speed boat out on the water at 2am and I thought someone would get killed; I thought it was crazy," she said.

Project officer for the Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation Tammy Gilson said the entire site was "incredibly significant" for the Wathaurung people.

"There needs to be resources put into educating people and it should be done in a consultative approach between all parties," Ms Gilson said.

"One of the biggest issues we face is the fact four wheel drives can essentially go where they like. I'd love to see areas that can not be accessed or out of bounds to protect the native vegetation.

"When it's not respected, the cultural values are taken away."

Ms Gilson said in the past, management plans had not gone anywhere.

"We're always about having a relationship with all bodies involved," she said.

"But it is such a big area, it's not something that can be monitored every day.

"You look at something like Lake Beaufort, which isn't nearly as big and it's got signage throughout. Here there's no signage, there's no education. We need all the assistance we can get."

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) has managed Lake Burrumbeet in partnership with the City of Ballarat, the Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation, Fisheries Victoria and the Glenelg Hopkins Catchment Management Authority since 2013.

The City of Ballarat manages the north-eastern recreation node including the Lake Burrumbeet Caravan Park as a Committee of Management.

DELWP's responsibilities include promoting natural values and recreation including protecting and maintaining the natural, cultural and historic values of the lake and enhance the balance between securing areas of environmental significance and appropriate recreational activities.

It is also in charge of encouraging ecological restoration of the reserve, managing grassy vegetation in the southern and western nodes to reduce fire fuel load and provide public amenity, manage pest plant and animals collaboratively with adjoining land managers and maintain safe access.

DELWP's Acting Regional Manager Land and Built Environment Programs John Downs said a full-time project officer was in the process of being appointed to manage a formal review of the Lake Burrumbeet management.

"The project has not yet commenced, but it is hoped that the management plan will be completed in spring and will begin to guide the management of the Lake for the 2018/19 summer," Mr Downs said.

"We commit to working with our partners, key stakeholders, including environmental groups and the community to ensure that all concerns and aspirations are considered in any alternatives developed.

"Consultations will be widely advertised at the time, to ensure representative opportunities.

Ms Moodie said she saw three important needs for the lake.

These include new governance which included one governing body for the lake, land and lake bed; the creation of an environmental sanctuary and restoration of ecosystems including aquatic habitats and water quality, native grasslands, wetlands and red gum woodlands and; a celebration of cultural heritage which preserve the archaeological, historical and geological features of interest.

General Manager of Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation Paul Davis said the management of the lake had been "haphazard".

"Traditional owners would be interested in a discussion. The organisation would like to see a proper plan for it," he said.

Mr Downs said recently installed signage had had an impact on lake users.

"We are really pleased with the positive reaction from lake users," he said.

"The recent Labour Day long weekend saw 300 visitors on each of Saturday and Sunday largely adhering to signs and advice to take their rubbish home.

"When Forest Fire Management Victoria crews returned to check the site after the weekend, there was very little rubbish left to clear away.

"DELWP Compliance Officers reported only a few breaches of camp fire regulations, with just four verbal warnings given over the entire weekend for fires not being in pits, and only one camp fire left unattended."

Mr Downs said poor behaviour should be reported to police if safe to do so. Littering should be reported to the EPA line on 1300 372 842.

urn:contentItem:5XRX-GF51-F0J6-J25R-00000-00AWM director should have museum management skills2019-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisAWM director should have museum management skillsLetters to the editor

A new director has been appointed for the Australian War Memorial. ("Veteran appointed as new director of the Australian War Memorial", canberratimes.com.au, December 14.

Despite his public service record I notice he has no qualifications or experience as a curator of any museums anywhere in the world.

It would make more sense to appoint someone with extensive experience in museum management and planning.

Someone with these qualifications would know it is not necessary to spend half a billion dollars on the extension and could work within the framework of the present building.

Tourists do not come to the Australian War Memorial to visit a fun park. They come to pay their respects to service personnel.

I cannot imagine Charles Bean would be impressed by the proposed development. It is, after all a war memorial, and does a wonderful job in its' present format.

Robyn Lewis, Raglan, NSW APS arrogance I find Michael White's letter concerning DFRB/DFRDB pensions deeply offensive (Letters, December 14).

This is particularly so with regard to his final paragraph (suggesting Mr Stone "could find a better way of assisting worthy veterans than by raising false hopes based on some perceived injustice that was never there").

Mr White's arrogance epitomises the attitude of many APS staff who deal with conditions of service for military personnel. Generally they resent any such conditions that equal or excel their own and work tirelessly to reduce such entitlements.

The introduction of the DFRDB scheme in 1972 was primarily to correct the abysmal conditions relating to entitlements under the existing Worker's Compensation legislation in the event of death or injury, not on active service, as well as to create an entitlement to commutation.

I do not believe that the Government Retirement Benefits Office have ever "suggested or inferred to any retiring member of the Defence Force" anything concerning entitlements ever. It is not within their remit.

Twice a year they advise all pensioners under the current schemes what their pension will be.

It is up to the personnel services of each of the services to advise existing and exiting service persons of their entitlements.

The individual retiree is left to fend for him or herself against both his old service, the GRBO and the DVA.

What is certain is that the RAAF system advised all personnel who were compulsorily transferred to the DFRDB scheme in 1972 that they had a right to commute their pension and if they did the reduced pension was calculated to have paid back the lump sum when they reached the age of 72.6 years when the full pension entitlement would be resumed.

Mr White and his fellow workers would undoubtedly have been in contact and advised the APS experts embedded within the individual services personnel systems as to the interpretation of the new DFRDB scheme.

Thus it is these people who fabricated the erroneous concepts that we service persons were briefed on. But why would they?

J Trinder, Karabar, NSW Prejudice apparent The fact Jennifer Killen (Letters, December 12) refers to "Israel's theft of Palestinian land" in the context of the disputed land on the West Bank (of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, as it was) demonstrates that she has pre-judged the issue that UN resolutions and the Oslo Accords, amongst others, said should be negotiated.

This attitude is part of the problem, as it encourages Palestinian intransigence; it is not part of the solution.

In any case, as Lee mentioned in his article, the Israeli offer included land in compensation for any West Bank land retained by Israel.

Sadly, the Palestinian leadership refused point blank, without even a counter-offer. At least Killen acknowledges that the settlements do only cover 1.1 per cent of the West Bank, in contrast to the ridiculous claims advanced by other advocates for the Palestinians.

Hopefully the Palestinian elections scheduled for next year will, if they go ahead, result in a leadership that actually cares more about the welfare of their people than "the cause", and will therefore be prepared to accept Israel's existence and negotiate in good faith.

Bill Arnold, Chifley Fire war footing On November 26 the Tallaganda Forest fire, started by a lightning strike, was only a few metres across. It quickly grew to encompass 40,000 hectares of death, destruction and trauma.

Here is a chance to make fuller use of the nation's defence investments. The government is purchasing General Atomics MQ-9B 'Sky Guardians', big uncrewed surveillance and attack drones.

If these $1.3 billion worth of weapons can put a missile through an ISIS commander's window then they can orbit our forests after lightning storms, detect nascent fires with FLIR and call in precision water drops.

Could the PM please call the chief of air force and instruct him that the planes must be outfitted to combat the truly terrifying threat of mega fires .

P Marshall, Braidwood, NSW Pipeline concerns The headline of the otherwise thorough report "Pipeline to boost water supply runs dry", (December 16, p4) is somewhat misleading.

Although our current water storage level appears worryingly low, at about 50 per cent capacity, it's on a base that includes the massive new Cotter Dam. It was built, essentially by the private sector, to monopolise the system.

That clearly oversized dam obviously caused the shutting down of the well-conceived, pre-existing $140 million Murrumbidgee River to Googong Dam pipeline (the subject of the report), very soon after the pipeline's completion, and years before the current drought.

Jack Kershaw, Kambah Atheists gospel I can't claim to speak for any atheists, but I expect that they are too broad a non-church to have a single unified agenda, other than that all religious claims and rights should be subject to examination and based only on evidence.

As for abortion, contraception, homosexuality, euthanasia or even smashed avo on toast, I'm not aware of Jesus spending a lot of his time outlining his views on these topics.

He did however have a bit to say about overly judgemental attitudes towards your fellow man, including the kind frequently put forward by some cranky old male self-appointed and monopolistic interpreters of the teachings of Jesus.

I'm sure that the divine spirit can find more inspired spokespersons than these; perhaps even women?

I think I will continue to prefer Jesus's more direct words, calling for a community of love, compassion and forgiveness, I'm happy to leave the smiting bits to the old testament.

Wishing you well in all things, I've got a birthday party to go to.

Garry P Dalrymple, Earlwood, NSW Let Greta be Mark Sproat (Letters, December 16) joins a long line of bitter old men who, irrationally, can't stand the thought of a 16-year-old girl having the courage to speak out for her future.

I'm probably older than Mark, yet I find it easy to enthusiastically applaud Greta and her generation who fear the consequences of the world's inaction on climate change.

It is people like Mark, led by the orange haired old man in the White House who ought to go back to school.

They need to learn the science and, critically, get over childishly sniping at Greta.

Eric Hunter, Cook Peak stupidity The UK election and collapse of the Madrid climate talks confirm my belief that during 2019 we passed peak stupidity.

Hopefully the influence of various prophets of doom, rent seekers, political opportunists, do-gooders and other instruments of darkness is now on the wane.

Here, the anti-coal factions have lost ALP support. In Germany the renewables industry is collapsing and in other places nuclear power is making a comeback with smaller, safer, more practical modular reactors and super-efficient, new-generation large plants.

China is buying huge quantities of Russian gas to keep world fossil fuel consumption at record highs and to demonstrate that while they pay lip service to the climate change hoax Chinese actions tell a different story.

Nowhere was this more obvious than at Madrid where the long-standing nonsense of transferring money from wealthy nations to poor ones under the pretext of reparations has been blocked, with China leading the pack.

The inevitable result of decades of exaggerations, failed predictions, guilt peddling and outright lies has been coming for a long time.

It has finally arrived.

With luck the momentum will continue, and having passed speak stupid in 2019, in 2020 we will enjoy the clarity of vision these figures have always represented.

Doug Hurst, Canberra TO THE POINT WASTE NOT, WANT NOT How seriously do some Federal government departments and large corporations take our dwindling water supply?

As I walk to work in the early hours of the morning I am witness to the ritual hosing down of hundreds of square metres of hard surfaces outside various buildings in the CBD. I'm sure there is a good reason.

Peter Duck, Kippax HEED THE EXPERTS If Albo wanted to develop an election winning manifesto, all he needs to do is pinch some ideas and advice from the letters page.

James Mahoney, McKellar RACE HAS NO PLACE I entirely agree with Greg Pinder's letter (December 16) hoping that any decision of the High Court in the case of the two Indigenous Australians facing deportation will not be decided on race.

By the same token, I hope any decision in regard to a special Indigenous voice in Parliament will not be decided on the basis of race either.

Bill Deane, Chapman AIR QUALITY CONCERN On December 15 it was reported that Canberra's air quality index had peaked at 650, the worst result since the 2003 fires.

But how long did the poor quality last in 2003? There has been smoke haze over Canberra this time at least since the night of Saturday, December 7.

That's seven days long and continuing on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of this week according to the Bureau of Meteorology.

Rod Holesgrove, Crace THE PIT NICKER A number of recent letters have been described as "nit-picking". When Mr. Morrison brought a lump of coal into the House of Representatives, could that be described as "pit-nicking"?

Peter Baskett, Murrumbateman, NSW SAINT GRETA... Greta Thunberg can be officially proclaimed a saint now that she has been canonised by Time Magazine. And so the farce continues.

P Wilson, Miami, Qld LACK OF SMARTS Those who refuse to believe in the reality of climate change should be subjected to an intelligence test.

Glenys Hammer, Narrabundah THE THREE STOOGES When I was a young we used to laugh our heads at the Three Stooges.

They are back. As the bossy Moe we have Trump, as the baby faced clown Curly we have Boris and as the easygoing simpleton Larry we have Scomo.

Even the old Larry would be hard pressed to come up with a skit involving carrying around a lump of coal as a raging inferno approaches, burning everything in its path.

John Holland, Dickson PRODIGIOUS PM Scott Morrison has made the biblical "Loaves and fishes" seem rather mangy when you look at his notice giving an additional $11 million to the fire effort.

D Fraser, Currumbin, Qld GET WARMING DONE The leading losers at the climate conference in Madrid were Australia, Brazil and the US. Let's get warming done.

Jochen Zeil, Hackett Email: letters.editor@canberratimes.com.au Send from the message field, not as an attachment. Fax: 6280 2282. Mail: Letters to the Editor, The Canberra Times, PO Box 7155, Canberra Mail Centre, ACT 2610.

Keep your letter to 250 or fewer words. References to Canberra Times reports should include date and page number. Letters may be edited. Provide phone number and full home address (suburb only published).

urn:contentItem:5RXY-F161-JD34-V4R1-00000-00Time to put Lake Burrumbeet back on the agenda say activists2018-03-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATETime to put Lake Burrumbeet back on the agenda say activistsGreg Gliddon

IT'S only eight minutes from the heart of Ballarat, but Lake Burrumbeet has become the forgotten jewel in the region's crown.

Despite being a world class area for wildlife and birdlife, the Friends of the Lake group and the traditional Indigenous owners believe for too long it has been left to rot, becoming a haven for antisocial behaviour and litter.

The Friends of the Lake Burrumbeet say it is time to start looking after one of the few natural wildernesses left in the western district.

"We want it to be a world class area for wildlife which is connected with birdlife," Friends of Lake Burrumbeet spokeswoman Susan Moodie said.

"It is home to 13 species of bat, it used to have eel, there used to be platypus, there are still some turtles around."

"We want to celebrate cultural diversity with joint signage and interpretations about what makes this place so unique in the world. That's what draws tourists. That's what people want to know.

"We need to say why it is important and the facilities need to reflect the beauty of the place."

Ms Moodie said since the City of Ballarat handed the responsibility of the lake to the state, "the management has been shocking".

"There have been three management plans, the first in 1986. None have been implemented," she said.

"Ballarat ceded its responsibility, its bylaws and oversight to the state. The decline in services has been unfortunate for visitors and the ecology of this reserve."

The problems at the lake were brought to stark realisation when anti-social behaviour at the campgrounds over the Australia Day long weekend turned a number of locals and campers away from the site.

Incidents including hooning, public drunkenness, extreme littering, and a dog attack all occurred in the space of a few days at the lake's campgrounds.

A camper who spoke to The Courier after the weekend said dangerous behaviour and fighting ruined the trip.

"We went to bed at about 10pm and the at about 2am a car, don't know how fast, flew along the dirt road and then there were two more cars possibly chasing it," she said.

"There were kids asleep in tents and swags everywhere and I was really worried."

She said she could hear people fighting all night and spent her night worried for her family's safety.

"It was feral, there was a speed boat out on the water at 2am and I thought someone would get killed; I thought it was crazy," she said.

Project officer for the Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation Tammy Gilson said the entire site was "incredibly significant" for the Wathaurung people.

"There needs to be resources put into educating people and it should be done in a consultative approach between all parties," Ms Gilson said.

"One of the biggest issues we face is the fact four wheel drives can essentially go where they like. I'd love to see areas that can not be accessed or out of bounds to protect the native vegetation.

"When it's not respected, the cultural values are taken away."

Ms Gilson said in the past, management plans had not gone anywhere.

"We're always about having a relationship with all bodies involved," she said.

"But it is such a big area, it's not something that can be monitored every day.

"You look at something like Lake Beaufort, which isn't nearly as big and it's got signage throughout. Here there's no signage, there's no education. We need all the assistance we can get."

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) has managed Lake Burrumbeet in partnership with the City of Ballarat, the Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation, Fisheries Victoria and the Glenelg Hopkins Catchment Management Authority since 2013.

The City of Ballarat manages the north-eastern recreation node including the Lake Burrumbeet Caravan Park as a Committee of Management.

DELWP's responsibilities include promoting natural values and recreation including protecting and maintaining the natural, cultural and historic values of the lake and enhance the balance between securing areas of environmental significance and appropriate recreational activities.

It is also in charge of encouraging ecological restoration of the reserve, managing grassy vegetation in the southern and western nodes to reduce fire fuel load and provide public amenity, manage pest plant and animals collaboratively with adjoining land managers and maintain safe access.

DELWP's Acting Regional Manager Land and Built Environment Programs John Downs said a full-time project officer was in the process of being appointed to manage a formal review of the Lake Burrumbeet management.

"The project has not yet commenced, but it is hoped that the management plan will be completed in spring and will begin to guide the management of the Lake for the 2018/19 summer," Mr Downs said.

"We commit to working with our partners, key stakeholders, including environmental groups and the community to ensure that all concerns and aspirations are considered in any alternatives developed.

"Consultations will be widely advertised at the time, to ensure representative opportunities.

Ms Moodie said she saw three important needs for the lake.

These include new governance which included one governing body for the lake, land and lake bed; the creation of an environmental sanctuary and restoration of ecosystems including aquatic habitats and water quality, native grasslands, wetlands and red gum woodlands and; a celebration of cultural heritage which preserve the archaeological, historical and geological features of interest.

General Manager of Wathaurung Aboriginal Corporation Paul Davis said the management of the lake had been "haphazard".

"Traditional owners would be interested in a discussion. The organisation would like to see a proper plan for it," he said.

Mr Downs said recently installed signage had had an impact on lake users.

"We are really pleased with the positive reaction from lake users," he said.

"The recent Labour Day long weekend saw 300 visitors on each of Saturday and Sunday largely adhering to signs and advice to take their rubbish home.

"When Forest Fire Management Victoria crews returned to check the site after the weekend, there was very little rubbish left to clear away.

"DELWP Compliance Officers reported only a few breaches of camp fire regulations, with just four verbal warnings given over the entire weekend for fires not being in pits, and only one camp fire left unattended."

Mr Downs said poor behaviour should be reported to police if safe to do so. Littering should be reported to the EPA line on 1300 372 842.

urn:contentItem:51MV-1GW1-JCVT-J532-00000-00Israeli fire put out but ire still burns2010-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 8Israeli fire put out but ire still burnsJASON KOUTSOUKIS, MIDDLE EAST CORRESPONDENT JERUSALEM

AS ISRAELI firefighters finally extinguished the worst forest fire in the country's history, a blaze that left 41 people dead and 5 million trees destroyed, the political fight over blame for the disaster was only just beginning. Most Israeli commentators were savagely critical of the country's lack of firefighting preparedness, forcing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu onto the defensive. Writing in the leading daily newspaper Haaretz, commentator Amir Oren said the fires were "Netanyahu's Katrina", a reference to US president George Bush's much-criticised handling of the hurricane that devastated New Orleans in 2005. "The politicians passed themselves off as purposeful responders to 3am phone calls.

In reality they didn't have a clue as to what to do when the phone rang at 3pm," Oren wrote. Speaking after a special cabinet meeting on Sunday, Mr Netanyahu said "massive forest fires are fundamentally different from routine fires". He said Israel was unashamed at having to request international assistance to fight the blaze, as had other countries, including Russia, the Ukraine and the United States, when faced with forest fires. "The issue of closing the gaps in the conventional, ground-based, not aerial, firefighting network is an important issue," Mr Netanyahu said. "The government has begun to deal with this issue, which has demanded a solution for 62 years." In the mass circulation daily Yedioth Ahronoth, analyst Alex Fishman said the fire undermined Israel's national security. Rabbi Ovadia Yossef, spiritual leader of the ultra-orthodox Shas party, said it was punishment for Israelis who did not observe the Sabbath. In his weekly sermon, Rabbi Yossef quoted a section of the Talmud that proclaimed "the fire only exists in a place where the Sabbath is desecrated". The blaze, which destroyed nearly 5000 hectares of pine forest in Israel's north, was extinguished late on Sunday. Two brothers, aged 14 and 15, from the Druze village of Isfiya were arrested on suspicion of causing the fire through negligence after a family picnic.

urn:contentItem:5G7Y-ND71-F0J6-J0SS-00000-00IN SHORT NON-FICTION2015-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMBooksPg. 28IN SHORT NON-FICTIONREVIEWS BY STEVEN CARROLL

PICK OF THE WEEK

Letters to My Grandchildren

DAVID SUZUKI

NEWSOUTH BOOKS, $29.99

Shockingly, in this series of essays addressed to his grandchildren, Suzuki uses the "C" word - capitalism, which is usually draped in euphemistic language such as "the marketplace" now. In deliberately simple language, Suzuki covers a range of topics; the Great Depression, its forgotten lessons, the post-war birth of relentless consumerism and planned obsolescence; the current state of the world reeling from being constantly used as a resource, citing "fracking" as one of the great insanities of the age; ageing, the cult of youth, atheism and the inevitability of death. In this letter he invokes the tale of the South American hummingbird that carries drops of water to a forest fire one at a time much to the amusement of its fellow creatures, responding to their laughter with the words "I'm doing the best I can". More than the marketplace wolves can say.

After Perfect

CHRISTINA McDOWELL

BANTAM, $34.99

The film The Wolf of Wall Street is one of those Fieldingesque tales featuring picaresque rogues that, to many, is emblematic of the crass excess of the 1990s. Intended as a cautionary tale, to McDowell, daughter of Tom Prousalis (a business associate of the real wolf, Jordan Belfort, who went to jail for fraud), the film romanticised the con-men it depicted. This is the tale from the daughter's point of view. No loveable rogues, just duplicitous cheats who cause tremendous damage to their families and society. McDowell, who changed her name, charts her family's fall from grace, and her own from privilege to working in seedy bars, homelessness, bit acting, drink and drugs. It's a record of the personal cost of those years, but also documents her forgiveness of her father and her gritty determination to go forward.

Good Muslim Boy

OSAMAH SAMI

HARDIE GRANT, $32.95

There are times when this memoir is reminiscent of migrant tales such as They're a Weird Mob, when we see our culture, rituals and colloquialisms through an uncomprehending outsider's eyes. The unfortunately named Osamah, a writer, actor and film-maker, weaves comedy and family tragedy together. In 2013 he went to Iran with his father, a leading Melbourne Shiite cleric, who suddenly died of a heart attack. One of two stories running through the book is about his struggle to get the body back to Australia before his visa expires. The other describes life in Iran during the Iran/Iraq war, before the family's arrival in Australia as refugees, landing in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, supporting the Essendon Bombers, negotiating the language. A funny, perceptive, distinctive voice.

Darjeeling

JEFF KOEHLER

BLOOMSBURY, $49.99

If market price is anything to go by Darjeeling is the champagne of teas, Koehler maintains in this readable history of the plant. It's an embracing study of a small leaf that goes back 2500 years to China, then on to key turning-points such as the establishment of the East India Company in 1600 and the importation of tea to Europe, especially England. At first it was the drink of aristocrats, then of the wealthy, then of the whole country. And, all the time, Darjeeling was the most expensive, the choice of connoisseurs. Koehler knows his brew and writes about it with great enthusiasm. The big question is will the tea survive the pace of economic change, a growing Indian middle class disinclined to be paid a pittance for plucking tea, and political unrest? Or, will it all end in teas?

urn:contentItem:5D5R-PW21-F0J6-J1SY-00000-00Arrest over massive inferno2014-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 39Arrest over massive infernoEmergency Thousands of Californian homes threatened - United StatesVeronica Rocha, Los Angeles

A 37-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the massive King fire in Northern California that exploded in size overnight and now threatens thousands of homes, authorities confirmed on Thursday.

Wayne Huntsman was booked on Wednesday on suspicion of arson and was being held in lieu of $US10 million bail, according to the El Dorado County Sheriff's Office.

Authorities planned to announce further details about the arrest later Thursday.

If California needed a reminder that it was suffering the worst drought - and the hottest year - in recent history, it came in a flash on Thursday, when the King fire tripled in size.

In the parking lot of the Camino Seventh-Day Adventist Church, where dozens of people took refuge after being chased from their homes by oncoming flames and walls of grey smoke rising from a ravine, the news of the arrest triggered outbursts of fury.

"They ought to put him in a helicopter and drop him onto the fire," said Doug Floyd, 73, a retired heavy construction carpenter, who had been at the church since Wednesday afternoon.

The King fire is burning a slice of gold country and national forest through the steep hills of the American River Canyon and the Silver Creek Canyon. The area is about 225 kilometres north-east of San Francisco. It is costing $US5 million a day to fight.

The out-of-control fire threatens more than 2000 homes in the Eldorado National Forest east of Sacramento after ballooning overnight from 11,300 hectares to nearly 27,900 hectares. Another 1500 buildings are threatened by the blaze, which was just 5 per cent contained on Thursday morning, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection. More than 3300 firefighters have been assigned to the blaze.

Meanwhile, the state's largest fire continues to be the Happy Camp Complex fire in Klamath National Forest. The fire, which began August 12 and has burned more than 50,000 hectares, is 68 per cent contained, the US Forest Service reported.

That blaze is made up of 15 fires, all of which were sparked by lightning.

The fires prompted California Governor Jerry Brown on Wednesday to declare a state of emergency for El Dorado County.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency granted a corresponding request for aid that can cover up to 75 per cent of the state's costs to fight the fire, one of several active wildfires burning in California.

The most destructive in terms of damage to property has been the Boles fire, which erupted late Monday and quickly tore through the logging town of Weed, just west of Mount Shasta. The fire damaged or destroyed more than 150 structures, including churches, a library and the town's sawmill.

In Madera County, the 130-hectare Courtney fire has destroyed 30 homes, 19 outbuildings and 13 vehicles. It was 70 per cent contained as of Wednesday evening.

TWO PHOTOS: More than 3000 firefighters face a daunting task to stop a raging forest fire north-east of San Francisco that suddenly tripled in size. Photos: AFP Arson suspect Wayne Allen Huntsman.

urn:contentItem:5G7Y-X551-F0J6-J1G2-00000-00IN SHORT NON-FICTION2015-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMBooksPg. 28IN SHORT NON-FICTIONREVIEWS BY STEVEN CARROLL

PICK OF THE WEEK

Letters to My Grandchildren

DAVID SUZUKI

NEWSOUTH BOOKS, $29.99

Shockingly, in this series of essays addressed to his grandchildren, Suzuki uses the "C" word - capitalism, which is usually draped in euphemistic language such as "the marketplace" now. In deliberately simple language, Suzuki covers a range of topics; the Great Depression, its forgotten lessons, the post-war birth of relentless consumerism and planned obsolescence; the current state of the world reeling from being constantly used as a resource, citing "fracking" as one of the great insanities of the age; ageing, the cult of youth, atheism and the inevitability of death. In this letter he invokes the tale of the South American hummingbird that carries drops of water to a forest fire one at a time much to the amusement of its fellow creatures, responding to their laughter with the words "I'm doing the best I can". More than the marketplace wolves can say.

After Perfect

CHRISTINA McDOWELL

BANTAM, $34.99

The film The Wolf of Wall Street is one of those Fieldingesque tales featuring picaresque rogues that, to many, is emblematic of the crass excess of the 1990s. Intended as a cautionary tale, to McDowell, daughter of Tom Prousalis (a business associate of the real wolf, Jordan Belfort, who went to jail for fraud), the film romanticised the conmen it depicted. This is the tale from the daughter's point of view. No loveable rogues, just duplicitous cheats who cause tremendous damage to their families and society. McDowell, who changed her name, charts her family's fall from grace, and her own from privilege to working in seedy bars, homelessness, bit acting, drink and drugs. It's a record of the personal cost of those years, but also documents her forgiveness of her father and her gritty determination to go forward.

Good Muslim Boy

OSAMAH SAMI

HARDIE GRANT, $32.95

There are times when this memoir is reminiscent of migrant tales such as They're a Weird Mob, when we see our culture, rituals and colloquialisms through an uncomprehending outsider's eyes. The unfortunately named Osamah, a writer, actor and filmmaker, weaves comedy and family tragedy together. In 2013 he went to Iran with his father, a leading Melbourne Shiite cleric, who suddenly died of a heart attack. One of two stories running through the book is about his struggle to get the body back to Australia before his visa expires. The other describes life in Iran during the Iran/Iraq war, before the family's arrival in Australia as refugees, landing in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, supporting the Essendon Bombers, negotiating the language. A funny, perceptive, distinctive voice.

Darjeeling

JEFF KOEHLER

BLOOMSBURY, $49.99

If market price is anything to go by Darjeeling is the champagne of teas, Koehler maintains in this readable history of the plant. It's an embracing study of a small leaf that goes back 2500 years to China, then on to key turning-points such as the establishment of the East India Company in 1600 and the importation of tea to Europe, especially England. At first it was the drink of aristocrats, then of the wealthy, then of the whole country. And, all the time, Darjeeling was the most expensive, the choice of connoisseurs. Koehler knows his brew and writes about it with great enthusiasm. The big question is will the tea survive the pace of economic change, a growing Indian middle class disinclined to be paid a pittance for plucking tea, and political unrest? Or, will it all end in teas?

urn:contentItem:53Y6-VB61-F0JP-W3P1-00000-00at a glance2011-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisCARSGUIDEPg. 72at a glance

MOTORCYCLES

LAVERDA CONCOURS RESCHEDULED

THE biggest showing of concours-standard motorcycles in Queensland is on this weekend in the annual Laverda Concours.

It was rained out earlier this year and the new venue is at the Cleveland Showgrounds, so it's now called the Cleveland Bike Show.

Run by Club Laverda Queensland, it had been hosted at Kangaroo Point since 1988. The new location allows the event to display more than 200 bikes.

The alcohol-free charity family day raises funds for the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

Admission is $5, with gates open from 8am-2.30pm.

Visit: clublaverdaqld.com

CLASSIC CARS

INVITATION-ONLY SHOW RETURNS

BRISBANE'S exclusive invitation-only classic car show is back.

After being flooded out in January, Speed + Style + Beauty has been moved to the Hamilton cruise terminal on November 25-27.

Organiser Rod Gould says it has already booked more than 40 rare cars from 1909 to 2011.

The show will be open on the Friday from noon-8pm, Saturday 10am-8pm and Sunday 10am-5pm. Cost is $15 adults, $12 concession and $5 children.

Visit: speedstylebeauty.com

CHARITY RIDE

BYRON BAY RUN FOR SICK KIDS

BIKERS are invited to enjoy a social ride to Byron Bay on October 16 and help support kids with cancer.

Heavy Duty Motorcycles has organised the 500km run that starts at and returns to its shop at 3409 Pacific Highway Access Rd, Springwood.

Registrations are from 8.30am and cost is $10 a person. The run starts at 9.30am and breakfast will be supplied. All proceeds go to Camp Quality.

Contact: 3208 3300.

BIKE RALLY

ADVENTURE MACHINES HIT ROAD

ADVENTURE riders of all bike brands are invited to join the TeamMoto Triumph Adventure RAT Rally on October 29-20.

Riders will leave from the Springwood TeamMoto store and stay overnight at the Cherrabah Resort, near Warwick.

Cost is $150, which includes dinner, breakfast and a souvenir T-shirt. Bikes must be registered adventure machines with dual-purpose tyres or knobbies.

The two-day 500km course will include tar and dirt roads and forest fire trails, but no single-track or off-road riding. Numbers are limited to 50.

Contact: teammoto.com.au

urn:contentItem:5PD9-JXG1-JD3N-52J9-00000-00Houston, we have a problem2017-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Houston, we have a problemPeter Boyer

The Texas floods stole our attention, but there were many other inundated places around the world, says Peter Boyer

DELUGED with news from Texas, we can be forgiven for thinking that Hurricane Harvey was the worst ever global weather.

Measured in lives and livelihoods lost, it did not come near last week's monsoonal flooding across Pakistan, India, Nepal and Bangladesh that has crippled food production over vast acreages and killed over 1200 people.

Many other recent rain events in (among other places) southern and eastern Asia, the Philippines, central and South America and Africa - too many to list here - have had a more devastating impact on lives and economies than Harvey. But they were not in a developed Western country.

It is a sad reality that global news puts far less focus on poor places than rich ones.

Houston is a big, bustling, wealthy city, supported by one of the biggest ports in the US and large chemical and research industries. That made Harvey very big news.

Nearly all of Houston's Fortune 500 companies (it has more of them than any US city, except New York) are involved in some way with oil and gas. Needless to say, they have so far had nothing to say about whether their industry might have contributed to the storm that wrecked the city.

It is true, as many people are keen to point out, that human-induced climate change and weather events are different phenomena, and that rain events have always happened and will continue to do so regardless of what we put into the atmosphere.

In 2005 Al Gore pointed out that a warmer world breeds stronger storms, believing that the drowning of New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina might alert his country to dangerous climate change.

He thought the same of ex-Hurricane Sandy when it smashed into New York in 2012. However, the only lesson learned from these events seems to be that people and governments do not like to dwell on bad memories.

Many senior politicians, including Texas Governor Greg Abbott, have claimed that big wind and rain events have no connection with climate change, man-made or otherwise.

Recent events like Typhoon Haiyan, which killed over 6000 people in 2013, and our own Cyclones Yasi (2011) and Monica (2015) had an apocalyptic feel to them. But while not always reliable, old records have turned up a few storms in the distant past that seemed comparable in size.

Commentators like me have learned to be wary of attributing big weather events to changing climate.

I have found it useful to avoid such discussion while focusing on the bleeding obvious - higher average temperatures, melting polar ice sheets and the like.

The social and political tensions in play during storm events inhibit talk about attribution.

Raising the topic of man-made climate change when homes have been inundated and people drowned (or when wildfires have incinerated homes and people) is, as they say, playing with fire.

But scientific method finds a way around inhibitions. Since Hurricane Sandy, various studies have identified extended polar jet streams as a major reason for storm systems staying stalled for long periods, allowing them time to take up more water from the sea and to dump more of it over land.

Add to that very warm, energising Gulf waters along with warm air above (warm air can hold more moisture) and you have a recipe for Houston's third "500-year flood" in three years, and by far its most damaging wind-and-rain event on record.

A 2015 US-Korean study found that while warmer ocean water inhibited formation of tropical cyclones overall, leading to fewer storms, it also increased the intensity of those that did form. In the same year a European study found a 12 per cent rise since 1980 in record-breaking rain events.

Across the continental divide in southern California at the weekend a crisis of an entirely different kind was playing out - the biggest forest fire in memory besieging the city of Los Angeles. It was the opposite face of the same stalled weather systems that caused the Houston floods.

Unlike devastated parts of south Asia, Houston is a rich city in a rich country. But with nearly 200,000 homes damaged or destroyed, 80 per cent of which lack flood insurance, the damage bill may be as high as $150 billion, far ahead of any past natural disaster in the US.

Add to that the economic cost of closing 10 Gulf coast refineries accounting for about 17 per cent of US refining capacity, and it's unsurprising that governor Abbott is calling for more national help.

In the past, Abbott has taken out law suits against federal climate regulations, and when campaigning to be governor in 2014 he railed about "political demagogues using climate change as an excuse to remake the American economy".

Harvey, which is having a fair shot on its own at remaking the economy, ought to change Abbott's mind about climate change, but that's unlikely given the powerful resistance across southern US states to identifying underlying causes of extreme weather events.

"I don't believe Hurricane Harvey is God's punishment for Houston electing a lesbian mayor," said widelysyndicated conservative commentator Ann Coulter on Twitter last week. "But that is more credible than 'climate change'." She offered no basis for her bald assertion. I suggest it's based on faith alone bolstered by 1.7 million Twitter followers, and with numbers like that behind you, who needs facts?

Peter Boyer began his journalism career at the Mercury in the 1960s. He specialises in the science and politics of climate change.

urn:contentItem:5PCN-4331-JBJ7-N216-00000-00'Heat spike' this weekend as winter loosens its grip on city2017-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexis'Heat spike' this weekend as winter loosens its grip on cityPeter Hannam

Winter's grip will finally feel like it's loosened amid a "heat spike" this weekend - even if that season's squeeze was not a very tight one.

Winter's grip will finally feel like it's loosened amid a "heat spike" this weekend - even if that season's squeeze was not a particularly tight one.

Nationally, Australia had its warmest winter by maximum temperatures since records began in 1910, with days on average 1.9 degrees warmer than normal. That beat the previous record winter in 2009 by 0.3 degrees.

One influence driving the abnormally mild condition was the band of high pressures that sat further south than normal over the continent, keeping cold fronts at bay. Climate change was also a factor.

"You have the underlying long-term warming trend," Blair Trewin, senior climatologist at the bureau, said. "Consistent with that, 19 of the last 20 winters have had above-average maximum temperatures."

Nationally, August was less extreme than June and July, with temperature anomalies less pronounced and better rains across south-eastern Australia helping to ease rainfall deficits in many areas.

Forest fire index levels, though, remain high, particularly for inland NSW, as authorities prepare for an early bushfire season.

For Sydney, the city had its driest winter since 2009. The 211.4-millimetre tally for the three months was about a third below average. July and August alone, though, were the driest in 22 years, Weatherzone said.

Sydney had its seventh-warmest winter for daytime temperatures, in line with last year.

The season also included the city's warmest July day on record, with 26.5 degrees on July 30 beating a record that had stood since 1990, the bureau said.

(See bureau chart below of average maximum temperatures.)

Brief burst of spring

Similarly warm conditions should return for the first weekend of spring, encouraging many to venture outdoors amid a "temporary heat spike", Graeme Brittain, a meteorologist from Weatherzone, said.

For those heading to the beach, "sheltered, south-facing beaches will be the place to go", particularly on Sunday when northwesterly winds pick up.

On current forecasts, Sydney is tipped to reach 22 degrees on Saturday and 28 degrees for a clear if windy Sunday.

Warmer conditions are on the way, at least for this weekend. Photo: Nick Moir

Spring's volatile weather will be on display, with large and powerful surf predicted for Saturday. Winds will also gradually strengthen on Sunday, reaching 50km/h as a cold front moves through, Mr Brittain said.

"It's a very cold air mass," he said, adding that it will knock daytime temperatures below the September average of 20 degrees for much of next week before conditions warm again by next weekend.

The cold front is also a dry one, as is the next one, meaning there is unlikely to be much rain relief soon for Sydney's threadbare playing fields.

"There's no really significant rain forecast for the next 14 days," Mr Brittain said.

Dry times

Those dry conditions also extend across much of the country after the driest winter since 2002.

Rainfall was about 43 per cent below the norm, the bureau said. (See chart below.)

NSW was notably dry, with about half the typical rain, or 58.8 millimetres. It was also the state's driest winter in 15 years.

Good rains in June meant only a small pocket of the state's north-east enjoyed above-average rain for the season.

For Sydney, rain fell on 22 days during winter, down from the average of 34 days. Just five of them had more than 10 millimetres, compared with eight such days in a typical winter.

With fewer rain clouds around, the city enjoyed sunnier-than-usual conditions, particularly in July and August.

Cool nights

One consequence of limited cloud cover, though, were cool nights, particularly for inland areas.

Sydney's nights remained milder above average for the city, but dropped below the winter average in western suburbs. Minimum temperatures in Parramatta, for instance, were 0.6 degrees below normal, the bureau said.

Likewise for NSW, central and southern parts of the state recorded below-average nights, often accompanied with frost.

Dr Trewin said Bathurst stood out as one location enduring extreme conditions during winter.

The town posted its highest average maximums for the season, its coldest average nights since 1927 and its driest winter on record.

Nationally, average minimum temperatures were 0.34 degrees above the long-term norm, although the cold was particularly centred over the country's south-east. (See bureau chart below.)

After a slow start, the ski season got a boost from some big dumps of snow. Spencer's Creek had 189 centimetres of snow at the end of August, the most since 2012.

More snow is expected in the coming weeks, Dr Trewin said.

The bureau's forecasts for spring, updated on Thursday, point to a switch in coming months towards more typical rainfall levels.

That news will be welcomed by farmers but also fire authorities, particularly in NSW, that are gearing up for an early and active bushfire season.

"The seasonal outlook for spring rainfall does lean to wetter-than-average conditions in a lot of the south-eastern corner of Australia, particularly along the east coast," Dr Trewin said.

"It does look like we're going to see a bit of a pattern shift," he said, although the change for some regions may not arrive until October.

urn:contentItem:7WR1-RHD0-Y9B7-54C4-00000-00QLD: Qld fire crews battle blazes in dry, windy conditions2009-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQLD: Qld fire crews battle blazes in dry, windy conditionsDavid BarbelerBRISBANE Sept 27

  Queensland fire crews are battling eleven blazes across the state, with continuing dry and windy weather conditions putting emergency services on high alert.
   The number of fires being monitored has jumped up by three since Saturday.


   A central Queensland fire, which started at Nine Mile Creek a few days ago and has since moved through to Struck Oil Road in Limestone Creek, is causing the the most concern.
   While five fire crews have cut off the blaze with containment lines and no homes are under threat, a spot fire broke out in the nearby Mount Morgan region on Saturday night.
   Five crews are also battling a forest fire in the National Park at Alice Creek in Bunya Mountains.
   The fire is now well inside containment lines and no property is threatened.
   Meanwhile, a grass fire in Peregian Springs that was believed to be under control flared up again at 3am (AEST) on Sunday morning.
   Five fire crews were dispatched to the fire, which is situated on Havana Road West, and were able to quickly contain the fire.
   Other blazes across the state include a bushfire at Nerang State Forest, a grass fire at Numinbah Valley, a grass fire at Mt Moffat, a grass fire at Booyal, a grass fire at Nanango, a grass fire at Ilbilbi and a grass fire at Mount Fox.
   While no properties near any of the fires are currently under threat, residents in affected areas have been asked to remain on high alert.
   The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service has extended fire bans in various parts of the State until 12.01am (AEST) this Monday.
   Bureau of Meteorology senior forecaster Ben Annels urged residents to be extra vigilant as dry and windy weather conditions were expected to continue across the state.
   "There's quite a few fires around, and with these conditions there's always the possibility new fires can start up," he said.

urn:contentItem:5PCN-4331-JBJ7-N233-00000-00'Heat spike' this weekend as winter loosens its grip on city2017-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexis'Heat spike' this weekend as winter loosens its grip on cityPeter Hannam

Winter's grip will finally feel like it's loosened amid a "heat spike" this weekend - even if that season's squeeze was not a very tight one.

Winter's grip will finally feel like it's loosened amid a "heat spike" this weekend - even if that season's squeeze was not a particularly tight one.

Nationally, Australia had its warmest winter by maximum temperatures since records began in 1910, with days on average 1.9 degrees warmer than normal. That beat the previous record winter in 2009 by 0.3 degrees.

One influence driving the abnormally mild condition was the band of high pressures that sat further south than normal over the continent, keeping cold fronts at bay. Climate change was also a factor.

"You have the underlying long-term warming trend," Blair Trewin, senior climatologist at the bureau, said. "Consistent with that, 19 of the last 20 winters have had above-average maximum temperatures."

Nationally, August was less extreme than June and July, with temperature anomalies less pronounced and better rains across south-eastern Australia helping to ease rainfall deficits in many areas.

Forest fire index levels, though, remain high, particularly for inland NSW, as authorities prepare for an early bushfire season.

For Sydney, the city had its driest winter since 2009. The 211.4-millimetre tally for the three months was about a third below average. July and August alone, though, were the driest in 22 years, Weatherzone said.

Sydney had its seventh-warmest winter for daytime temperatures, in line with last year.

The season also included the city's warmest July day on record, with 26.5 degrees on July 30 beating a record that had stood since 1990, the bureau said.

(See bureau chart below of average maximum temperatures.)

Brief burst of spring

Similarly warm conditions should return for the first weekend of spring, encouraging many to venture outdoors amid a "temporary heat spike", Graeme Brittain, a meteorologist from Weatherzone, said.

For those heading to the beach, "sheltered, south-facing beaches will be the place to go", particularly on Sunday when northwesterly winds pick up.

On current forecasts, Sydney is tipped to reach 22 degrees on Saturday and 28 degrees for a clear if windy Sunday.

Warmer conditions are on the way, at least for this weekend. Photo: Nick Moir

Spring's volatile weather will be on display, with large and powerful surf predicted for Saturday. Winds will also gradually strengthen on Sunday, reaching 50km/h as a cold front moves through, Mr Brittain said.

"It's a very cold air mass," he said, adding that it will knock daytime temperatures below the September average of 20 degrees for much of next week before conditions warm again by next weekend.

The cold front is also a dry one, as is the next one, meaning there is unlikely to be much rain relief soon for Sydney's threadbare playing fields.

"There's no really significant rain forecast for the next 14 days," Mr Brittain said.

Dry times

Those dry conditions also extend across much of the country after the driest winter since 2002.

Rainfall was about 43 per cent below the norm, the bureau said. (See chart below.)

NSW was notably dry, with about half the typical rain, or 58.8 millimetres. It was also the state's driest winter in 15 years.

Good rains in June meant only a small pocket of the state's north-east enjoyed above-average rain for the season.

For Sydney, rain fell on 22 days during winter, down from the average of 34 days. Just five of them had more than 10 millimetres, compared with eight such days in a typical winter.

With fewer rain clouds around, the city enjoyed sunnier-than-usual conditions, particularly in July and August.

Cool nights

One consequence of limited cloud cover, though, were cool nights, particularly for inland areas.

Sydney's nights remained milder above average for the city, but dropped below the winter average in western suburbs. Minimum temperatures in Parramatta, for instance, were 0.6 degrees below normal, the bureau said.

Likewise for NSW, central and southern parts of the state recorded below-average nights, often accompanied with frost.

Dr Trewin said Bathurst stood out as one location enduring extreme conditions during winter.

The town posted its highest average maximums for the season, its coldest average nights since 1927 and its driest winter on record.

Nationally, average minimum temperatures were 0.34 degrees above the long-term norm, although the cold was particularly centred over the country's south-east. (See bureau chart below.)

After a slow start, the ski season got a boost from some big dumps of snow. Spencer's Creek had 189 centimetres of snow at the end of August, the most since 2012.

More snow is expected in the coming weeks, Dr Trewin said.

The bureau's forecasts for spring, updated on Thursday, point to a switch in coming months towards more typical rainfall levels.

That news will be welcomed by farmers but also fire authorities, particularly in NSW, that are gearing up for an early and active bushfire season.

"The seasonal outlook for spring rainfall does lean to wetter-than-average conditions in a lot of the south-eastern corner of Australia, particularly along the east coast," Dr Trewin said.

"It does look like we're going to see a bit of a pattern shift," he said, although the change for some regions may not arrive until October.

Weatherzone is owned by Fairfax Media, publisher of this website.

Weatherzone is owned by Fairfax Media, publisher of the Herald.

The big dry

For NSW it was the 10th driest winter since 1910 and also the driest since 2002, with half the average rainfall in the state.

Australia's record warm winter

1.9 degrees above average

Maximum temperatures across Australia were nearly 2 degrees above the 1961-90 average for winter. Beating the previous record, set in 2009, by 0.3 degrees.

urn:contentItem:7W9R-8SM1-2PW5-F0H4-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Aug 52009-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Aug 5

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
US: Bill Clinton wins reporters' freedom from NKorea
   SEOUL, Aug 5 AFP - Former US president Bill Clinton has secured the release of two female US journalists jailed in North Korea after a surprise mercy dash to meet veteran communist leader Kim Jong-Il in Pyongyang. (KOREA JOURNALISTS 7th Update sent at 07:52, 676 words.)


US: Families 'overjoyed' by news of NKorea pardon
   LOS ANGELES, Aug 4 AFP - The families of two US journalists jailed in North Korea said Tuesday they were "overjoyed" by news that former president Bill Clinton had secured their release on a historic trip to Pyongyang. (KOREA JOURNALISTS 6th Update sent at 07:27, 261 words.)
US: Obama celebrates two birthdays: his and veteran journalist's
   WASHINGTON, Aug 4 MCT - President Barack Obama, born 48 years ago Tuesday in Honolulu, Hawaii, celebrated his first birthday in the White House with a family breakfast in the private residence, a birthday song at lunch sung by senators in the State Dining Room and a song of his own for the dean of the White House press corps: columnist and veteran wire service correspondent Helen Thomas, who turned 89. (US OBAMA BIRTHDAY Update sent at 08:03, 338 words.)
US: Felicia reaches hurricane strength in Eastern Pacific
   WASHINGTON, Aug 4 AFP - Felicia has reached hurricane strength in the Eastern Pacific more than 2,000 kilometres west-southwest of Baja California in Mexico, the US National Hurricane Center says. (FELICIA sent at 07:03, 78 words.)
Australia, New Zealand to help Canada fight fires
   VANCOUVER, Canada, Aug 4 AFP - Australian and New Zealand firefighters are to help battle forest fires sweeping through western Canada and threatening a historic gold rush town, a statement says. (CANADA FIRES Update sent at 05:42, 432 words.)
ASIA: Pilot dead, 42 hurt after Thai jet skids off runway
   BANGKOK, Aug 4 AFP - A pilot has been killed and seven people were hospitalised after a Bangkok Airways jet skidded and hit an old control tower as it landed on Thailand's resort island of Ko Samui, the airline said. (THAI PLANE sent at 05:01, 432 words.)
SAM: Outcry over Venezuelan media crackdown
   CARACAS, Aug 4 AFP - Claims that Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez is waging an all-out attack on independent media escalated on Tuesday after an armed group forced its way into the main remaining opposition television network. (VENEZUELA RADIO sent at 03:38, 469 words.)
CHN: China plague toll rises to three: report
   BEIJING, Aug 5 AFP - The death toll from an outbreak of pneumonic plague in northwest China has risen to three, state media has reported as authorities maintained a quarantine lockdown on a town of 10,000 people. (CHINA PLAGUE sent at 03:34, 503 words.)
AFR: Clinton kicks off Africa tour in Kenya
   NAIROBI, Aug 4 AFP - US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton began a tour of seven African states on Tuesday in Kenya, where she will seek action to stabilise neighbouring Somalia and push for free trade with the continent. (AFRICA CLINTON Update sent at 03:05, 397 words.)
CAM: Ousted Honduran president in Mexico to meet Calderon
   MEXICO CITY, Aug 4 AFP - Honduran President Manuel Zelaya has turned to Mexico for help in reviving negotiations over his ouster from power amid rising regional tensions punctuated by a shooting death near Honduras' border with Nicaragua. (HONDURAS sent at 00:30, 518 words.)
AFR: Protests erupt at Sudan woman's trouser trial
   KHARTOUM, Aug 4 AFP - Sudanese riot police used tear gas against hundreds of people demonstrating outside a Khartoum courtroom on Tuesday in protest at the trial of a woman who faces 40 lashes for wearing trousers. (SUDAN LASHES sent at 00:19, 555 words.)
EUR: Spain's La Palma island forest fire under control
   MADRID, Aug 4 AP - A forest fire on the Canary Island of La Palma was brought under control on Tuesday and another that raged for two weeks in Spain's northern Catalonia region has been extinguished, an emergency official said. (SPAIN FIRE sent at 00:09, 317 words.)
UK: Calls for inquiry over British torture allegations
   LONDON, Aug 4 AFP - Calls for an inquiry are growing in Britain after lawmakers said the government was hiding behind a "wall of secrecy" over allegations that agents colluded in the torture of terror suspects abroad. (UK TORTURE Wrap sent at 22:03, 627 words.)
SAM: Brazil forest group: Go green - go in the shower
   RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug 4 AP - New TV ads are encouraging Brazilians to save water - by urinating in the shower. (BRAZIL URINATE sent at 07:24, 142 words.)

urn:contentItem:459X-PHS0-0197-B3SS-00000-00<published>1997-11-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:46:21Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 44</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>MAPPING THE THREAT</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">UNDERSTANDING how fires behave - particularly the fires that ravage bushland in the height of summer - is the subject of Project Vesta, a major six-year study about to start in Western Australia.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Building on existing knowledge, Project Vesta will develop a standard system for land managers around Australia to predict the spread and intensity of wildfires.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The project - involving WA's Department of Conservation and Land Management and the CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products Division - has the backing of the Australasian Fire Authorities Council.</p><p>Knowledge gained will help determine the hazards of different types of fuel and enable more accurate mapping of the threat of wildfires.</p><p> CALM executive director Dr Syd Shea said CALM's Forest Fire Behavior Tables, developed from more than 30 years of research, had proven invaluable in predicting fire behavior during low to moderate intensity fires.</p><p> The tables apply to both prescribed burning and wildfire suppression.</p><p> "These tables - known as CALM's Red Book - are internationally recognised as a leader in predicting fire behavior," Dr Shea said.</p><p> "However, we need to update our research data to meet the more exacting needs of contemporary fire management.</p><p> "Project Vesta will significantly increase our understanding of how fuel characteristics affect fire behavior.</p><p> "Understanding fire behavior is critical to the safe and efficient control of wildfires as well as in planning fire prevention strategies, particularly for rural communities and those in areas such as the hills to the east of Perth."</p><p> CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products' chief Dr Glen Kile said that during the devastating NSW bushfires in 1994, fires spread much faster than predicted by the McArthur Forest Fire Danger meter, widely used in south-eastern Australia to predict fire behavior.</p><p> "The more accurately wildfire behavior can be predicted, the more effective fire control measures will be," he said.</p><p> Fire behavior is determined by fuel, topography and the weather, particularly wind.</p><p> During Project Vesta, scientists from CSIRO and CALM as well as those from Canada, NSW, South Australia and Victoria, will light a series of 4ha fires and measure how the fires' rate of spread is influenced by the amount and type of fuel and wind speed.</p><p> Two sites in the jarrah forest have been selected - one inland from Harvey and the other west of Nannup.</p><p> Some of the experimental plots have not been burned for 19 years, resulting in a big build-up of leaves and twigs that dry out in summer and become flash fuels for wildfires.</p><p> The sites have a range of understorey age classes so the contribution of live shrubs to wildfire behavior will also be studied.</p><p> Detailed measurements of the structure, arrangement and distribution of the various fuel components have been recorded and analysed by scientists.</p><p> These analyses indicate a practical system of identifying fuel structures can be developed for dry eucalypt forests and woodlands.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5FWG-YX91-F03R-N54F-00000-00Study: Thinking Can Speed Up Brain Tumour Growth2015-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisStudy: Thinking Can Speed Up Brain Tumour GrowthVittorio Hernandez

Apr 27, 2015( International Business Times Australia: http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Thinking can fire up nerves in the brain and can lead to the proliferation of brain tumours, experts from Stanford University said last week. According to Cell, activity in the cerebral cortex has an impact on high-grade gliomas, which account for 80 percent of malignant tumor cases today.

The Stanford researchers discovered this through an experiment on mice implanted with human brain cancer.<nl/> "This tumor is utilizing the core function of the brain, thinking, to promote its own growth," said the study's author Michelle Monje, a researcher and neurologist at Stanford, according to NPR.org[1]. To test their hypothesis, the researchers used optogenetics, a method that uses light to control brain cells to stimulate cell activity within the tumour site. Surprisingly, it worked.<nl/> "We don't think about bile production promoting liver cancer growth, or breathing promoting the growth of lung cancer," Monje was quoted as saying by Medical Express[2]. "But we've shown that brain function is driving these brain cancers."<nl/> "Our new findings indicate that this metaphorical forest fire has been difficult to extinguish because there is something akin to gasoline seeping up from the soil."<nl/> The results point to further research on the other causes of brain cancer and how to stop its growth. The cause of glioma is still unknown. The origins of glioblastoma, one type of rare glioma arising from astrocytes, is also yet to be uncovered, according to the American Brain Tumor Association. Glioblastoma accounts for 52 percent of all glioma cases worldwide.<nl/> About 50 percent of patients diagnosed with the disease die within a year, while 90 percent of patients die within three years of diagnosis. In Australia, 1,000 people are diagnosed with brain cancer annually, a report on The Courier Mail revealed[3]. Forty percent of patients die within 14 months of diagnosis due to recurrence, while only three to five percent of patients live beyond five years.<nl/> The Courier Mail also noted that a series of trials using clinical drug KB004[4] will be launched this year, 2015, in Brisbane for subjects suffering from recurring glioblastoma. The clinical trials will be held at the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital and the Austin Hospital in Melbourne. It will be conducted by QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute and will involve 20 participants.<nl/> US-based company Nascent Biotech[5] (OTC:NBIO[6]) is also working on developing a similar therapy that can be used to treat brain cancer. Based on human immunoglobulin antibody, the therapy, Pritumumab, has been granted orphan drug designation by the US Food and Drug Administration recently.<nl/> Pritumumab was derived from the B-cell of a tumour-draining lymph node of a patient suffering from cervical cancer, the company's website[7] revealed. It targets ecto-domain vimentin, a novel target and protein expressed on the cell surface of malignant tumors. The target has not been pursued by any other biotechs in the company's niche. Pritumumab has an overall response rate of 25 to 30 percent among patients.<nl/> To contact the writer, email: v.hernandez@ibtimes.com.au;<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2015/04/23/401723235/thoughts-can-fuel-some-deadly-brain-cancers [ 2]:   http://medicalxpress.com/news/2015-04-brain-tumor-growth-nerve-cortex.html [ 3]:   http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/brisbane-scientists-to-begin-human-trials-for-what-could-be-biggest-breakthrough-in-brain-cancer-treatment-in-decades/story-fnn8dlfs-1227134358866 [ 4]:   http://kalobios.com/kb004 [ 5]:   http://www.nascentbiotech.com/ [ 6]:   http://finance.yahoo.com/q?s=NBIO [ 7]:   http://www.nascentbiotech.com/products/pritumumab/

urn:contentItem:5326-K0F1-F0JP-W201-00000-00Thousands flee fire2011-06-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:46:21ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 14Thousands flee fireUS SPRINGERVILLE, Arizona, Tuesday

A HUGE wildfire in the US state of Arizona that has forced thousands from their homes, is now the second largest in the state's history.

Flames from a huge forest fire licked the ridges surrounding the eastern Arizona town of Eagar, forcing the evacuation of about half the 4000 residents.

People started streaming out of Eagar on Tuesday as sheriff's deputies and police officers directed traffic. Flames were spotted on a ridge on the southeastern side of nearby Springerville and columns of orange smoke rose from the hills.

Ash rained from the sky, which was filled with thick smoke, and when the sun peeked through, it was blood-red.

The blaze has burned 1259sq km of ponderosa pine forest, driven by wind gusts of more than 96km/h since it was sparked on May 29 by what authorities believe was an unattended campfire. On Tuesday, it became the second-largest fire in Arizona history.

No serious injuries have been reported, but the fire has destroyed 10 structures so far. It has cast smoke as far east as the state of Iowa and forced some planes to divert from Albuquerque, New Mexico, some 320km away.

Joe Reinarz, commander of a firefighting team battling the so-called Wallow fire, told residents that the fire was within 3km of Springerville and Eagar.

Crews were trying to keep the flames away from Eagar and Springerville law enforcement officers patrolled the evacuated areas.

Eagar has about 4000 residents, while Springerville has another 2000. In all, about 7000 people have been ordered to prepare for evacuation in recent days.

Several tiny resort towns in the nearby Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest were evacuated earlier. Winds whipping the fire drove the last residents from Greer.

Haze was being carried by a ridge of high pressure as far as central Iowa, said Kyle Fredin, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Denver. The smoke was also visible in New Mexico, Colorado, Nebraska and Kansas.

The state's largest blaze came in 2002 when flames blackened more than 1895sq km and destroyed 491 homes.

A fire in 2005 burned about 1002sq km in the Phoenix suburb of Cave Creek and consumed 11 homes.
